Title: Seminar: Hosted by Chemistry and Biochemistry
Body:
January 9, 2013
GM315
 
The Sagle Group At The University Of Cincinnati:  Single Protein Patterning Using Colloidal Lithography
 
Dr. Laura Sagle 
Department of Chemistry
University of Cincinnati
 
The Chemistry Department at the University of Cincinnati offers a diverse, stimulating atmosphere to carry out graduate studies.  An overview of the Chemistry Department and the University of Cincinnati will be presented along with some recent results on a new project in the Sagle group involving protein patterning for biosensing applications.  Colloidal lithography is a cheap, easy to fabricate, bench top technique, however, achieving patterning on small scales has proven problematic.  Recent advances to traditional colloidal lithography provide the ability to pattern on unprecedented small scales, ~10 nm.  This allows for the exciting possibility of patterning single protein molecules on a surface, which offers optimal control over orientation and aggregation for various biosensing platforms.

Title: 3D Event
Body: The Mathematics Department's new 3D workstation will be unveiled at the  Computational Biology & Biochemistry meeting:  When: 10th period this Friday (January 11th) Where: G220 Crapo Hall  The following structures will on display at atom level resolution in 3D!  1) The polio virus. 2) A bacterial ribosome, a molecular factory that manufactures proteins  and that is the target of several antibotics. 3) The estrogen receptor, the protein that binds female sex hormone  estradiol. 4) The androgen receptor, the protein that binds male sex hormone  testosterone.  Professor Brandt from the Chemistry and Biochemistry Department will  provide a guided tour of the structures listed above.  Everyone is welcome to attend.  Yosi Shibberu Mathematics Department

Title: SimplyWell Speaker - Stress Management - Wednesday, January 30, 2013
Body:
Stress Management
Wednesday, January 30, 2013
2:30 – 3:20 p.m.
HMU – Kahn Room
 
Presenters: 
Ashleigh Schulwitz, Student Counseling Services
Mike Latta, Director of Student Counseling Services
 
Join us for a presentation on stress management. Mike and Ashleigh will present on some of the common causes of stress and what we can do to help manage the stress in our lives.

 
To sign up, please log on to ANGEL and choose ROSExperience. Spouses are welcome to attend this event! 
 
SimplyWell participants may earn 250 points under the Wellness Events category. Please log on to www.simplywell.com and enter your points within 90 days of this session.
 
If you have any questions, please contact Pam Pahnke at ext. 8916.

Title: ROOMATE(S) NEEDED
Body: We are looking for one or two roommates to help us fill our 5 bedroom house conveniently located less than 10 minutes from campus. (6 miles) Less than $500 a month gets you EVERYTHING! Including food. That's $6,000 a year, compare that to living on campus at around $10,000! House is in a beautiful wooded area and includes 5 bedrooms, 3 bathrooms, 2 living rooms complete with 47" TV's with entertainment system, a large deck, a kitchen, and wait for it...a POOL. Plus, your rent will also include internet access and access to DISH TV in your room. The house is already completely furnished and ready to go. If you are interested, please email us back as soon as possible. No commitment here or anything, we just need to know who is interested so we can discuss further details.

Title: Selling Textbooks
Body:
Hey everybody, I totally recommend using The Rose-Hulman Campus Exchange to buy books. It doesn’t seem to be that popular but it’s a good place to sell/buy textbooks for cheap. And speaking of selling books, I have several that some of you might find you need for your classes coming up next quarter. 

They are for the following classes:
•	MA190 Contemporary Math Problems, $10.00
•	IA350 Intermediate Microeconomics, $100.00
•	MA381 Intro to Probability w/Stats, $50.00
•	CSSE120 Intro to Software Dev., $30.00

All the prices can change, as I’ll take the best offer, but I hope everyone saves some money on textbooks next quarter since we’re already paying enough just to go here.

If interested, just email me at robertcg@rose-hulman.edu, call me at (317) 777-3010, or stop by my room (Lakeside 122). Thanks, I’m Cody Roberts.

Title: Change a Life, Become a Mentor
Body:
Do you have an interest in helping others?  Do you enjoy sharing your knowledge and experiences? If so, this may be the perfect opportunity for you.
The Office of Human Resources is hosting a Professional Development Seminar:  Change a Life, Become a Mentor.  Please join Dawn Blankenbeker on Tuesday, February 5, 2013 from 1:35 - 2:25 pm in the Heritage Room to learn more about Rose-Hulman’s Mentoring Program, the benefits of mentoring and how sharing your knowledge, skills, and experiences can translate to the success of others.   
This seminar is open to current and prospective mentors.  
Please register via ANGEL on or before February 5, 2013.

Title: Detox, Energize, Clear Your Skin, Get Healthy and Possibly Lose Weight
Body:
Hi Everyone!  So the holiday season has ended with lots of memories and gifts that we've brought back with us! But with all that happiness, most of us brought back a few things we could all live without during the holidays:  the stress, the fatigue, and those 3-5 extra pounds that seem to come oh-so-easily.

Being here on campus, it is easy to get caught up in homework, deadlines, family, significant others and activities and our health takes a toll as a result. 

I say its time to take care of yourself and your body. That's why I want to invite you to experience winter quarter differently than you ever have before -- to enjoy every single moment of the season without feeling that overwhelming guilt and worry that hangs over us like a cloud. Let's wake up after finals week lighter and leaner than you are right now! Let's do this together. Register for my 28-Day Nourish and Evolve and join others across the country who are starting the program together.  I will teach you everything you need to know to breeze through the holidays with confidence and control you need. Let's start the New Year WAY and get ahead of your resolutions.

Register for a 7, 14, or 28 day detox and tell them that Rose sent you! http://www.snenutrition.com/ 

Here's what you get when you register for the program: 
Here's a few things you will have when you register for my program:

    *A Prep Week to help ease your way in so that you can start learning, planning, setting your goals and connecting with other participants.
    *A guided 5 Day Reset Detox & Cleanse with 5 full days of food, no stimulants and no hunger
    *A guided 13 Day Adjust New Eating Plan in which you will eat 5 healthy meals and snacks per day
    *28-Days of Supportive Materials from me, delivered to your inbox daily via videos, handouts, shopping lists, recipes and action steps
    *You'll feel Lighter!  You’ll likely lose weight if you're body needs to; (5-8lbs) 
    *You'll have More Energy.  You will be able to do more things you love.
    *You'll be More Productive.  As you feel better and can stay more focused.
    *You'll have a strong sense of Confidence.  That comes from taking care of yourself and your new, renewed energy
    *You'll have a happy and positive semester! 

Don't wait! Isn't it time you did something for yourself? You deserve it. And I'm going to help you get that feeling of confidence that you will radiate throughout the holidays. Register now!  http://www.snenutrition.com/ 

Need something sweet that doesn't leave you feeling guilty? I'm going to share one of my free recipes with you, filled with deliciousness and nutrition. My vegan, gluten free, diabetes friendly, raw brownie recipe will leave you wanting for more. Perfect for those holiday parties and make the whole family happy!

Ingredients:

    2 1/2 Cups Medjool Dates (Pitted, soaked in warm water for 5 mins)
    2 Cups Raw Walnuts 
    1/2 Cup Unsweetened Cacao
    1/2 Cup Unsweetened Cacao Nibs (optional, but highly recommended)
    1 Cup Raw Almonds (chopped, and soaked overnight)
    2 TBS Chia Seeds 
    for sweeter brownies add 1 TBS of agave nectar
    Pinch Himalayan Crystal Salt

Directions:
1. In a food processor, blend walnuts into a fine ground.
2. Add cacao powder and salt and pulse to combine then add dates individually until the mixture becomes ‘crumby.’
3. In a square pan, press the walnut/cacao mixture down firmly pressing in the almonds, chia seeds and cacao nibs into the mixture.
4. Freeze for at least 2 hours and then slice into eighteen squares.


If you have more questions, please contact (text/call) 301-752-1425 or rose@whatcanyou.be (haftrm@rose-hulman.edu) or twitter @whatcanube for more details!

Title: Hey, Can we borrow some helmets?
Body:
So a group composed of a few of my friends and I is going to be leaving on Saturday to explore Buckner Cave in Bloomington, IN.  We're already borrowing some helmets from the climbing club, but our party keeps growing and the amount of helmets we have isn't
TLDR
DO YOU HAVE CAVE OR CLIMBING HELMETS THAT MY FRIENDS WOULD BE ABLE TO BORROW FOR A DAY?

Title: Selling Samsung Droid Charge
Body:
I have a Samsung Droid Charge 4G LTE I received for Christmas in 2011. It's in great condition (just a few minor scratches on the front and back) and has had a screen protector for most of the time I've had it. I'll include two otterbox cases (commuter & defender), a kick-stand case by verizon, an extra battery, and a docking station (total retail of ~$100 right now from Amazon).

I have the original box (it's back at home in Colorado though) but I have the original cable, wall charger, and 32 GB micro SD card with me. The phone has a clean ESN and is ready for activation (requires a qualified data plan).

It's a great phone but I upgraded to a HTC Windows Phone 8x and don't need this one anymore

I'm asking $225 obo (open to trades within reason)

(If someone commits to buying this within 4 days of posting I'll throw in some screen protectors and a car charger)

If interested contact me at tubbcc@rose-hulman.edu

Title: Entrepreneurship - Terre Haute Startup Weekend - Feb 8-10
Body:
Startup Weekend is coming to Terre Haute !! February 8 - 10.

http://terrehaute.startupweekend.org/

Below is some information from the website.
----------------------------------------------------------
Ever wondered what it takes to be an entrepreneur?

Startup Weekend is a global grassroots movement of active and empowered entrepreneurs who are learning the basics of founding startups and launching successful ventures. It is the largest community of passionate entrepreneurs with over 400 past events in 100 countries around the world in 2011.

All Startup Weekend events follow the same basic model: anyone is welcome to pitch their startup idea and receive feedback from their peers. Teams organically form around the top ideas (as determined by popular vote) and then it’s a 54 hour frenzy of business model creation, coding, designing, and market validation. The weekends culminate with presentations in front of local entrepreneurial leaders with another opportunity for critical feedback.

Whether entrepreneurs found companies, find a cofounder, meet someone new, or learn a skill far outside their usual 9-to-5, everyone is guaranteed to leave the event better prepared to navigate the chaotic but fun world of startups.

Title: Climb tree, ride bike, play GLADIATOR BALL!
Body:
Are you tired of never having played Gladiator Ball?!  Well come on down to the SRC fieldhouse tomorrow at 7 PM and change all that! 

I don't need to tell you that Gladiator Ball is one of the toughest sports around.  I don't need to tell you that Gladiator Ball is a lot like volleyball in the way that it is played on a v-ball court.  And I'm sure that you are already aware that unlike volleyball, Gladiator Ball has a 15 ft gap in the middle, designated 'No Man's Land', instead of a net. And of course, as you are already aware, it consists of hurling a 12lb, beachball size, semi-cushioned medicine ball at the opposing team, scoring as the ball plows through the enemy and strikes the floor. 

Is this a sport for the weak of heart and body? Nay!  I say once more, NAY! Why should I waste my breath declaring that penalties result in 10 burpies for the player who beefed, when you already know this?!  

And why do you already know these things? Because you've been waiting for the chance to partake in the sport of bravery, the sport of valor, the sport of courage THAT IS GLADIATOR BALL since you were a wee lad (or lass)!

Here's a link of myself, family, and friends playing. 
https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?v=10151228488861378&set=vb.504156377&type=2&theater

Be warned: Gladiator Ball requires commitment.  If you are not sore the day following playing this, then you are made out of titanium, you're clearly a superhero, and should obviously be out fighting crime instead of sleep deprivation and anxiety disorders which Rose so graciously affords her children.

A bare minimum of 10 players is needed, but 12 works the best. If you are interested, send me, Bruce, an email at costonbj@rose-hulman.edu or text me at 219-369-3191 so I know we have enough fearless players to make this happen. All students and faculty are invited!

Title: North TH home for sale
Body:
Posting this for a friend...

For sale by owner for $64,900. We are moving because of a career change. This is a well-built three bedroom ranch home just north of the Terre Haute, Indiana city limits, east of Clinton Street and south of Sky King Airport. We are only the second family to live here as it was built in 1963 for the previous owner. We have lived here since 1996. We are moving because of a career change. The house is move-in ready. We just had a home inspection to prepare for selling and are working to repair the few things that needed attention. The house is situated at the end of a cul-de-sac in a modest and safe neighborhood. Quiet and very conducive to kids playing. The house is plain and simple but nice. Find much more information at http://sellhousebyowner.info and lots of pictures. Or call (812) 236-5470.
 
We will show the house by appointment only, but we will do our very best to accommodate your busy schedule.

Title: Selling 3D Displays
Body:
I'm selling my two (2) Sony Playstation 24" 3D displays, hardware for mounting them, and a dual monitor mount.

Asking $200 for each display or $380 for everything (mount, mounting hardware, 2 displays, 2 glasses, 2 HDMI cables). These retail for $250 each now (used to be $500 each) and the mount and mounting hardware was another $65.

Title: Webinar on Nutrition and Cancer Treatment by Johns Hopkins Medicine
Body:
Please join us for our next webinar entitled: What’s Food Got To Do With It: Eating Healthy During & After Cancer Treatment on Tuesday, March 12, 2013 at 7pm EST

During this webinar, we will discuss nutrition, weight management, diet, and changes in appetite during and after cancer treatment. This will include foods that may have healing properties, whether an organic diet is essential, what supplements are recommended, if there are foods that should be limited or avoided, exercise recommendations, and how to incorporate a healthy diet in your everyday life.  There will be plenty of time for live Q & A.

This webinar is open to all so please feel free to forward.


Registration is free.  To register, go to: http://bit.ly/NutritionCancerTreatment 

For questions please contact Elissa Bantug- ebantug1@jhmi.edu  or Rose at haftrm@rose-hulman.edu

Title: Student Poster Competition--IEEE Professional Communication Conference
Body:
Undergraduate and Graduate Students: Electronic Poster Competition at IPCC 2013

The IEEE Professional Communication Society (PCS) invites student submissions to the Electronic Poster Competition at the 2013 International Professional Communication Conference (IPCC 2013), which will be hosted by the University of British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada (July 15 - 17, 2013).

Conference Theme
Beyond Borders: Communicating Globally. The theme explores how communication technologies shape, alter, and reinvent global communication; how existing and new technologies erode borders between knowledge producers and knowledge consumers; and, how today’s engineers are preparing to communicate in the global workplace.

Electronic posters on other technical communication-related topics will also be considered. Suggested topic areas include, but are not limited to:
•         Cross-cultural communication
•         Engineering communication
•         Managing information and communication systems
•         Information quality
•         Humanitarian aid communication
•         Engineering management
•         Training and consulting
•         Visual/multimedia communication
•         Health/environmental communication
•         Information and communication security
•         Technical and professional communication pedagogy
•         Usability
•         Information design
•         Tools/techniques for collaboration
•         Content management/document technologies
•         Accessibility and Software user assistance

 
Who Can Participate
Graduate and undergraduate students are invited to submit electronic posters representing projects related to the conference theme or any other area of technical communication. All winning electronic posters will be displayed on a large monitor during the entire conference. 

Electronic Submission Guidelines
•         A self-explanatory, one-page PDF version of the electronic poster in a landscape orientation. The poster will not be printed and the student will not be presenting. Name the PDF file LastName_FirstInitial_IPCC2013
•         A 300‐word abstract about the electronic poster explaining its technical or research topic, including an explanation of how the poster succeeds in communicating the message visually. Name the file LastName_FirstInitial_Abstract_IPCC2013
•         Create a Dropbox account (www.dropbox.com), name the folder Lastname_Firstname, and invite ipcc.2013.poster.competition@gmail.com to share the folder containing the poster PDF and the abstract, no later than 15 May 2013.

Winner Selection
Undergraduate and graduate level posters will be judged separately. The competition committee, comprising both academic and practitioner members of PCS, will evaluate the content and design of all posters. The self-explanatory posters must visually illustrate and briefly explain technical projects or research studies related to the conference theme or other topics related to the field of professional communication. 

Judging Rubric for Electronic Poster Competition: (http://sites.ieee.org/pcs/files/2012/11/poster_-rubric_IPCC_2013.pdf) 

Awards
The competition committee will notify the winners by 30 June 2013. In each level, first place and second place winners will be awarded cash prizes. Third place winners from each level will get honorable mentions. All winning posters will be displayed on a large monitor during the conference. Winning posters will not be printed, and students will not be presenting. 

Deadlines
•         15 May 2013: Deadline for poster submission
•         30 June 2013: Winner notification
Questions
Contact ipcc.2013.poster.competition@gmail.com 
For more information about the conference, visit http://pcs.ieee.org/ipcc2013/
 

--Karina Allen
      Poster Competition Chair, IPCC 2013
      ipcc.2013.poster.competition@gmail.com

Title: SimplyWell Speaker - The Basics: Memory Loss, Dementia, and Alzheimer’s disease
Body:
The Basics: Memory Loss, Dementia, and Alzheimer’s disease

Wednesday, March 6, 2013
2:30 – 3:20 p.m.
HMU – Heritage Room
 
 
Presenter: 
Sarah May, Alzheimer’s Association, Greater Indiana Chapter
 
Sarah May will discuss the basics of Alzheimer's disease and will present the warnings signs.
 
To sign up, please log on to ANGEL and choose ROSExperience. Spouses are welcome to attend this event! Space is limited.
SimplyWell participants may earn 250 points under the Wellness Events category. Please log on to SimplyWell's website and enter your points within 90 days of this session.
If you have any questions, please contact Pam Pahnke at ext. 8916.

Title: ECE books for sale
Body:
I'm now taking bids on a few textbooks, and I'll certainly give you a better deal than the bookstore if you're interested.  I'm told some are outdated but still good enough for classes.  Caveat emptor.  I'm selling for: ECE 310, ECE 250/351, ECE 340/341, ECE 414, ECE 380, ECE 203/204, and ECE 362.  

In other words, that's CommSys, EDM/Analog, Emag, Wireless Systems, DT Signals, Circuits/Esys/EEE, and Junior Design.  And there's a Freshman Physics lab book that you can resell at a small profit, but only if you're the enterprising sort of person (you are, aren't you?).

Contact me at my Rose-Hulman email address-- petersbs@rose-hulman.edu --if you are interested in negotiating prices.  I may or may not post to that book website people keep whining about. Please excuse any formatting errors in this posting.

Title: Live Well Think Well (Wellness) Competition
Body: Live Well Think Well

Title: IM Swim Meet Registration Begins
Body:
* Registration for the IM Swim Meet begins today.  Please log onto www.imleagues.com to sign-up for the events you would like to compete in during the meet.  The registration deadline is Friday, March 15th and the meet will be held on Tuesday, March 19th.  Also, this year we will again be holding the IM Belly Flop Contest, which will begin immediately after the meet.  You can register for the Belly Flop Contest on IMLeagues as well.  If you have any questions or concerns, please feel free to contact Dan O'Leary at ext. 8987 or oleary2@rose-hulman.edu. 
 

 
IM Swim Meet & Belly Flop Contest
 
Who:  Open to all Rose-Hulman students (not 2012-2013 Rose-Hulman swim team members - divers may compete as long as they did not compete in any varsity swimming events.), faculty, and staff.  Male and Female participation are both strongly encouraged!!!  We will have both a Male and Female Champion for each event and division;  Greek, Res Hall, and Independent.
 
What:  Intramural Swim Meet & Belly Flop Contest.  There will be 8 different swimming events followed by the Belly Flop Contest.
 
When:  Registration begins today, Monday, March 4th.  The registration deadline will be Friday, March 15th.  Please log onto www.imleagues.com and register for the events that you would like to compete in.  The meet will be held on Tuesday, March 19th and will begin at 6pm.
 
Where:  The meet will be held in the Sports and Recreation Pool.
 
Why:  Intramural points (2 points per event) will be awarded to the winning Res Hall, Independent, and Greek participants towards the Intramural All Sports Championship.  Also, the overall winning Res Hall, Independent, and Greek team will receive 15 points.  Awards will also be given to the winners (mugs or t-shirts).
 
Costs:  This event is FREE!!!
 
Additional Information:  Information pertaining to the IM Swim Meet is attached to this posting.  Rules, events, and more detailed info can also be found on the IM webpage www.rose-hulman.edu/Intramurals/IM_Classic.  If you have any questions or concerns, please feel free to contact Dan O'Leary at ext. 8987 or oleary2@rose-hulman.edu.  Thanks and have a great day!
 
Order of IM Swim Meet Events:
200 Yds. Freestyle
50 Yds. Butterfly
100 Yds. Individual Medley
(butterfly, backstroke, breastroke, freestyle)
50 Yds. Freestyle
50 Yds. Backstroke
200 Yds. Medley Relay
(backstroke, breastroke, butterfly, freestyle)
50 Yds. Breastroke
200 Yds. Freestyle Relay
Belly Flop Contest
 
Dan O'Leary
Coordinator for Intramurals, 
Club Sports and Special Events
PHONE:    812-877-8987
CELL:        812-201-7903
5500 WABASH AVENUE
TERRE HAUTE, IN  47803-3920

Title: Selling TRX + Workout DVD's!!
Body:
I have a TRX and 2 accompanying workout DVD's (Cardio and Strength) that give complete workout exercises. If you don't know what a TRX is, it is basically an adjustable band in the shape of a Y with handles that you can attach to almost anything and used to do different workout exercises.

Check out this video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LtKSYFlpoTM.

With a TRX, you can work out your arms, legs and core with ease. It is also ideal for beginners and experts. It is very portable and works great for small apartments or dorm rooms. 

If you are interested, please email hoffmann@rose-hulman.edu. Thank you.

Title: Want to study in Japan?
Body:
Today at 4:30 in the Kahn Room, there will be an information session about studying at the University of Aizu in Japan.  U of Aizu offers programs in computer science, computer engineering, and software engineering, and most classes are offered in English.  You don't need to speak Japanese to participate in this program, and there is financial support from the Japanese government to fund you.

Come by today to learn more about Aizu and to meet Aizu students who are currently studying here at Rose.  Refreshments will be provided!  Presented by the Office of Global Programs, Myers 246, global@rose-hulman.edu

Title: Learn LabVIEW for FREE
Body:
Would you like to learn LabVIEW and become a Certified LabVIEW Associate Developer (CLAD) for free?  I will be doing another session of LabVIEW Workshops during Spring quarter.  There will be a series of 7 workshops (each will be approximately 1 hour), and at the end of the workshops, you get to take the CLAD exam for free (the total cost of materials to teach the topics that will be covered to yourself and to take the CLAD is usually nearly $1000).  If you are interested in learning LabVIEW and becoming certified for free, please email me (schwiean@rose-hulman.edu) by this Saturday (3/9) so I can accommodate as many people's schedules as possible.  Here is a link if you’d like to learn a little more about LabVIEW: http://www.ni.com/labview/. 

Have a great night!
-Alex Schwier, LabVIEW Student Ambassador

Title: Technical Presentation by ECE Candidate, Brian Degnan
Body:
Where is my jetpack?!?
 
Brian P. Degnan, PhD 
CTO for pocketpico.com
Friday, March 8
7th period 1:35 p.m.
D114
 
Abstract:
 
Consumer products have been pushed into smaller and smaller packages, and our processing capabilities have  increased due to better processing technologies (a la Moore's Law), but the quest for cool in the portable world is still burdened by the battery. Furthermore, Moore's Law has failed us and most "improvements" in processing performance have largely been due to slick advertising, and redefinitions, instead of true improvement in processing power.  I describe the trends in silicon-based scaling and battery energy storage as they are today, and what we can do to leverage existing technologies and methods to improve power consumption in the devices of tomorrow.

Title: Reminder: SimplyWell Speaker - The Basics: Memory Loss, Dementia, and Alzheimer’s disease - Today
Body:
The Basics: Memory Loss, Dementia, and Alzheimer’s disease

Wednesday, March 6, 2013
2:30 – 3:20 p.m.
HMU – Heritage Room
 


Presenter: 
Sarah May, Alzheimer’s Association, Greater Indiana Chapter

Sarah May will discuss the basics of Alzheimer's disease and will present the warnings signs.
 

To sign up, please log on to ANGEL and choose ROSExperience. Spouses are welcome to attend this event! Space is limited.
SimplyWell participants may earn 250 points under the Wellness Events category. Please log on to SimplyWell's website and enter your points within 90 days of this session.
If you have any questions, please contact Pam Pahnke at ext. 8916.

Title: Learn@Lunch - Basic Car Repair
Body:
Basic Car Repair
Wednesday, March 20, 2013
Facilities Garage
11:45 a.m. - 12:35 p.m.
Susan Reynolds, Manager of Facilities Support Services
and 
Mark McKinney, Garage Mechanic
 
Is your car in need of minor repairs? 
Have you had a flat tire and wished you knew how to change it?  
If so, this is an opportunity for you to learn about basic car repairs.
 
Please join Susan and Mark as they demonstrate some basic car repairs including: checking fluid levels and tire pressure; how to change a windshield wiper blade; locating information in your manual about maintenance schedules and more.
 
Participants are encouraged to bring a sack lunch to the event, 
tables and chairs will be set up.
Please register on ANGEL.
 
If you have any questions, please contact Dawn Blankenbeker at ext. 8245.

Title: Free iPhone 5 case
Body:
Yea!
It is true that you can get an awesome iPhone case for FREE!
I bet that it is the best iPhone case you have ever seen!
These common iPhones are always come with a plastic case and
a picture. They look similar even though they are from different brands.
Today, I bring you a new kind of case – they are beautiful and functional.
On the back of this case, there is a special light filling
with the sense
of future, and it will turn brighten and dark slowly and alternately,
like breathing.


How Can I get it?
You can get it for free by follow following steps:

your iPhone5, and tell me why you want it.
·        
6 lucky guys will be selected to get this case
and they will get a notice no later than this Friday.
·        
Get this case with a Deposit of $50.
·        
Write a review. (You can also make one more
video and upload it to YouTube if you want).
·        
Get the $50 back and keep this cellphone case.
 
And….The best 2 review-writers will get one more case as prize.

Title: Sign Up Now, Grand Challenges/LAP Case Study Competition
Weaver Undergraduate Research Awards Request for Proposals - Summer 2013
Body:
Through the generosity of Joseph and Reba Weaver, Rose-Hulman will award several grants to support undergraduate research.  Proposals are invited from individual students in collaboration with a faculty mentor.
 
Awards will be made to individual students for up to a total of eight weeks during the summer of 2013 as follows: $2500 stipend and on-campus housing.  Students who decline RHIT housing shall not receive other housing support. Equipment and supply costs for the research must be provided by the department(s) hosting the research.   
Currently enrolled freshmen, sophomore, and junior students in good standing (not on any kind of probation) are eligible.
 
Application deadline is Sunday March 24, 2013.  Proposals must be submitted electronically to Dr. Allen Broughton (brought@rose-hulman.edu) with a subject heading “Weaver Grant Proposal.”  Scanned copies of signature pages will be acceptable.    Award notification will be made by April 9, 2013.  Funds must be expended by August 31, 2013. 
 
Awardees will be required to submit a written report of the research (to Dr. Allen Broughton) and give a presentation to members of the Rose-Hulman community. The report and presentation must completed by May 31, 2013.  Awardees will not be permitted to engage in any other paid work at Rose-Hulman or Rose-Hulman Ventures during the period of the award.
 
For complete information please see the attachment. 
For more general information and past proposals see this webpage http://www.rose-hulman.edu/mapub/weaver/home.html

Title: ECE Faculty Candidate Technical Talk
Body:
On the Merits of Signaling Faster than the Channel Nyquist Rate
Yong Jin Daniel Kim
McGill University, Montreal, QC, Canada
Thursday, 3/14/13 – 1:35 – 2:30 
D114
 
Future telecommunication systems are expected to support large data rates in order to meet the growing demand for data-heavy multimedia contents and applications. Currently, most digital communications systems are built to transmit at the Nyquist rate of twice the channel bandwidth, motivated by the simple transmitter and receiver architectures. In this talk, we will explore the benefits of transmitting data faster than the Nyquist rate of the continuous-time bandlimited channel.
 
The main goal of this talk is to identify the fundamental merits and potential applications of the faster-than-Nyquist (FTN) signaling. We demonstrate that the FTN signaling can have competitive capacity benefits over the conventional Nyquist-rate systems in many practical scenarios, including the conventional point-to-point communication systems, frequency-selective channels, and multi-user broadcast channels. Consequently, low-complexity FTN coding architectures are proposed to explore the feasibility of achieving this improved capacity at a wide range of spectral efficiencies. These results indicate that FTN has a potential to become an integral technology for the next generation digital communication systems including wireless cellular systems, digital TV broadcasting, and fiber-optic communication systems.

Body:

Body:
Going on vacation this summer?
  Will stay in your home and care for your pets.
  Includes:
     Taking in mail and newspaper
      Watering houseplants

Charges: Minimum charge $100 a week plus stocked kitchen for breakfast and lunches. This price includes care for one pet.

     Additional mileage fee may apply if you live outside of Terre Haute.
     Pets must be able to be on their own for up to 8 hours a day
 
  Make your reservations early before time slots get filled. References available upon request.
     Jacki Moore jacquelinesmoore@gmail.com
     Jessamyn Moore jessamynmoore@gmail.com

Title: SimplyWell Speaker - Tax-Smart Ways to Save and Invest - Wednesday, March 27, 2013
Body:
Tax-Smart Ways to Save and Invest
Wednesday, March 27, 2013
10:50 – 11:40 a.m. OR 1:35 – 2:35 p.m.
HMU – Heritage Room
 
Presenter
Erin Robertson, TIAA-CREF
 
Take three important steps to identify potential areas for saving money:
1. Reduce the taxes you pay on earnings.
2. Reduce the amount you spend.
3. Make ‘tax-smart’ choices to keep more of what you earn.
 
We’ll discuss:
· Effective withholding strategies
· Tax-favored financial products
· Roth and Traditional IRAs
· Basic investment strategies
 
To sign up, please log on to ANGEL and choose ROSExperience. Spouses are welcome to attend this event! Space is limited.
SimplyWell participants may earn 250 points under the Wellness Events category. Please log on to SimplyWell's website and enter your points within 90 days of this session.
If you have any questions, please contact Pam Pahnke at ext. 8916.

Facilities Garage

and

Title: Art Show Luncheon
Body:
Art Show Luncheon
 
You are cordially invited to our spring luncheon! Here are the details:
 
Date:                    Wednesday, March 20th
Time:                   11:30: Lunch (Bring your own or Faculty Dining Room)
                   12:00: Program
Place:         Kahn Room, Hulman Memorial Union
Speaker:     David Erickson, Retired Professor, ISU Dept. of Art
RSVP:        Judy Hoover, at keith.hoover@rose-hulman.edu or 
                   877-3920. Please respond by Monday morning, March 18th.
 
Our speaker will be presenting a program highlighting the evolution of his artwork from early days to the present. Among his more recent works is the beautiful mural in the Terre Haute Children’s Museum.  He is currently working on a mosaic to be displayed at Fairbanks Park, on the banks of the Wabash, in honor of the Year of the River.  Professor Erickson will be bringing many examples of his work as well as a power point presentation.
 
Please plan to attend, in support of our club and our speaker.  The program will be great, the socializing is always fun, and you will also have a chance to view the annual Rose-Hulman Art Show in the Union lobby. We sure hope to see you there!

Title: ECE Faculty Candidate Presentation
Body:
Technical  Presentation
Eric Larson
University of Washington
 
Monday, 3/18 - 8th hour
2:30 - 3:25 - D114
 
Abstract 
Linear predictive coding is one of the most well-known algorithms used in speech compression and a number of various applications. In this lecture I will explain a subset of the applications of linear prediction, with classical demonstrations of its use in spectrum analysis and vocoding. I will also develop the mathematical foundations for calculating linear predictive coefficients and demonstrate more recent uses of linear prediction in health and wellness sensing from mobile phone microphones. The lecture is geared towards electrical engineering students, but is suitable for anyone with an engineering or computer science background.

Title: IM Home Run Derby!!

* The annual IM Wiffleball Home Run Derby will be held next Tuesday (March 26th) at 6:30pm in the SRC Hulbert Arena. No need to pre-register, just sign up at the registration table set up outside of Hulbert Arena by 6:15pm. There will be a limit of 50 participants for this event, so please arrive by 6:15pm to insure your spot in the competition.



IM Wiffleball Home Run Derby

Who: Open to all Rose-Hulman students (not Rose-Hulman Baseball or Softball Players), faculty and staff. There will be a limit of 50 participants for this event, so please arrive early to insure your spot in the competition. Male and Female participation are both strongly encouraged!!! We will have both a Male and Female Champion for each division; Greek, Residence Hall and Independent. We will have both a male bracket and a female bracket for each round of the derby.

What: Intramural Wiffleball Home Run Derby Competition. Each participant will receive pitches until they obtain 10 outs. Foul balls, swinging strikes and balls that do not clear the “fence” will count towards the 10 outs.

When: Tuesday, March 26th @ 6:30pm. 

Where: Hulbert Arena in the SRC.

Why: Intramural points will be awarded to the winning Residence Hall, Independent, and Greek participants (5 Points) towards the Intramural All Sports Champion. Awards will also be given to the winners.

Additional Details: No need to pre-register. Please arrive at the registration table just outside of Hulbert Arena in the SRC by 6:15pm on Tuesday, March 26th to sign up. There will be a limit of 50 participants for this event, so please arrive early to insure your spot in the Home Run Derby. More details and competition rules are attached to this posting.

Title: IM Softball Games moved into SRC for Wednesday and Thursday!!
Body:
Softball Captains,
 
Looking ahead at the weather for Wednesday and Thursday, the forecast does not look good. Both days will have temperatures in the low 30s/high 20s with strong winds. Due to this, the Intramural department has decided to move all softball games scheduled for Wednesday and Thursday, March 20th and 21st into the SRC. Instead of softball, all games will be wiffleball. 
 
The game schedule will stay the same, meaning your team will face the team that was scheduled against you in softball. Game times will be the same as they are scheduled for softball.
 
These games will count in your softball team’s record!
 
Rules will be the same as softball (unless noted below), with 3 pitches allowed by a pitcher that is a member of the hitting team.
 
Additional Rules for games in the FIELDHOUSE:

There are no homeruns unless a batter makes it around all 4 bases while the ball is in play.
If the ball is hit fair and gets STUCK  in the net or ceiling, it is a dead ball and a re-pitch. This means the hit and pitch do not count, the batter returns to the batter’s box and tries again. For example, if the batter hits pitch #2 and it gets stuck in the net, when he/she returns to the batter’s box, he/she will face pitch #2 again.

Note: Every curtain, ceiling, light, or apparatus used to hang the curtains is considered in-play, meaning balls can hit and bounce off of these things. It is only a re-pitch if the ball gets stuck in such a place. 
A fair ball that is hit and rolls or bounces under the curtains surrounding the courts is considered a ground-rule double. 
 
Additional Rules for games in the ARENA:

If the ball is hit fair and gets STUCK  in the ceiling, it is a dead ball and a re-pitch. This means the hit and pitch do not count, the batter returns to the batter’s box and tries again. For example, if the batter hits pitch #2 and it gets stuck in the ceiling, when he/she returns to the batter’s box, he/she will face pitch #2 again.
A fair ball hit onto the balcony will be ruled a home run.
Note: Every wall, bleacher, ceiling, light, or railing is considered in-play, meaning balls can hit and bounce off of these things. It is only a re-pitch if the ball gets stuck in such a place

Thank you and please let me know if you have any questions!
 
Dan O'Leary
Coordinator for Intramurals, 
Club Sports and Special Events
PHONE:    812-877-8987
CELL:        812-201-79035500 WABASH AVENUE   CM 37
TERRE HAUTE, IN  47803-3920
www.rose-hulman.edu

Title: Living in Terre Haute this Summer?
Body:
Are you living in the Haute this summer?
This summer, my roommates and I would like to sublet our apartment. We live in Sycamore Terrace, the apartments by Walmart on 46, so you will be close to campus, Ventures, and the store. We are asking for $425 a month per person to cover rent, but we will cover the utilities (water and electricity) provided they stay reasonable (under $100 for each utility).
 This may seem a bit high, but each room will come fully furnished as well as the following amenities:
For each room:
Bed with ALL Necessities including Sheets, Pillows, and Comforter  
Desk
Dresser and/or Closet
Also available to you:
Washer
Dryer
Great Internet
Cable TV
Home Theater System with HD Projector, Blu-ray Player, and Surround Sound
Wireless Color Printer
Pool
Work Out Room
Great AC
Close to Campus!
Close to Ventures!
We will only have two rooms to rent out as I am staying in town and will be using my room.
 If you are interested, please email me at gorebk@rose-hulman.edu .
 Have a great day, and we hope your third week goes well!

Title: March Madness Pick'em Registration Deadline
Body:
* Registration for the March Madness Pick'em ends tomorrow at 12:00pm (Noon). 
 
 
The deadline to register for the tournament is Thursday, March 21st, which is the day the tournament begins. Please be sure to log onto www.espn.go.com and register for the tournament before games begin.


 
IM March Madness Pick'em

Who: Open to all Rose-Hulman students, faculty, and staff. We will have a winner from the res hall, greek and independent divisions. As well as a male and female winner for each division.

What: Intramural March Madness Pick'em. 

When: Registration begins today, Friday, March 15th. The registration deadline is Thursday, March 21st before games begin. Once games begin you will not be allowed to enter a bracket.

How to Register: Visit the ESPN College Tournament Challenge at http://games.espn.go.com/tournament-challenge-bracket/en/frontpage. If you already have an ESPN account go ahead and sign-in. If not, you will need to create on account, which is FREE! After signing into the Tournament Challenge click "Join a Group". We have set up 3 different private groups; one for Greek, one for res hall, and one for independent. Please sign up in the group that you would like to represent (for example: if you are in a fraternity sign up for RHIT IMs Greek). The group ID and password is below:

Group ID: RHIT IMs Greek, RHIT IMs Res Hall, or RHIT IMs Independent (depending on what division you want to sign up for)
Password: intramurals 

Cost: Free!!!

* If you have any questions or concerns about the pick'em league or have any problems registering, please contact Dan O’Leary at ext. 8987 or oleary2@rose-hulman.edu. 


Thanks,
Dan O'Leary

Club Sports and Special Events

Title: Curious about the "MOOC" experience?
Body:
Stanford University is again offering a set of Massively Open Online Courses – free of cost, and typically requiring between 1 and 5 hours of work per week.  Among the offerings are a couple of entrepreneurship courses, a creativity course, and a course on designing a new learning environment.
 
If you are curious about the "MOOC" experience, this is a good opportunity to explore.
 
http://venture-lab.stanford.edu
 
Kay C Dee

Title: Rreminder - Weaver Undergraduate Research Awards Request for Proposals - Summer 2013
Body:
Through the generosity of Joseph and Reba Weaver, Rose-Hulman will award several grants to support undergraduate research. Proposals are invited from individual students in collaboration with a faculty mentor.

Awards will be made to individual students for up to a total of eight weeks during the summer of 2013 as follows: $2500 stipend and on-campus housing. Students who decline RHIT housing shall not receive other housing support. Equipment and supply costs for the research must be provided by the department(s) hosting the research. 
Currently enrolled freshmen, sophomore, and junior students in good standing (not on any kind of probation) are eligible.

Application deadline is Sunday March 24, 2013. Proposals must be submitted electronically to Dr. Allen Broughton (brought@rose-hulman.edu) with a subject heading “Weaver Grant Proposal.” Scanned copies of signature pages will be acceptable. Award notification will be made by April 9, 2013. Funds must be expended by August 31, 2013. 

Awardees will be required to submit a written report of the research (to Dr. Allen Broughton) and give a presentation to members of the Rose-Hulman community. The report and presentation must completed by May 31, 2013. Awardees will not be permitted to engage in any other paid work at Rose-Hulman or Rose-Hulman Ventures during the period of the award.

For complete information please see the attachment. 
For more general information and past proposals see this webpage http://www.rose-hulman.edu/mapub/weaver/home.html

Title: The Biomedical Engineering Seniors will present their capstone design projects
Body:
The Biomedical Engineering senior class will be presenting their capstone design projects Wednesday, March 27, in room E104, from 9:40 a.m. to 1:35 p.m.  Everyone is welcome to attend any or all of the presentations – details below!
9:40 a.m.         Welcome
 

9:45 a.m.         The Stable-izer
                        A device to be used in equine-assisted therapy that detects when the rider of a horse is leaning away from the vertical position and sounds an alert when the rider needs assistance to correct his or her posture.
                        Team: Genuine Risk Engineering
                              Creasy Clauser
                              Tanya Colonna
                              Alex Schwier
                                Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.
 

10:01 a.m....... Cornstarch Dispensing System
                        A device to allow persons with cognitive and/or physical disabilities to more easily and neatly complete the employment task of filling small bags with cornstarch.
                                Team: BEC Engineering
                              Emily Lakes
                              Carley Shumate
                              Brianne Widmoyer
 
                                Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.
 

10:17 a.m....... Leg Brace Redesign
                        A leg brace with a flexible knee joint that will allow a person with post-polio syndrome to walk with an improved gait cycle.
                        Team: Brace Yourself
                              Stephen Kays
                              Nick Pilipovich
                              Mac White
                                Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.
                                      

10:33 a.m.       Bowling Ball for Individuals with Disabilities
                        A bowling ball designed for use by individuals with low grip strength and/or neuromuscular control.
                        Team: The Perfect Game
                              Sam Brooks
                              Adam Dills
                                                
                                Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.
                        

10:49 a.m.       Treadmill Modifications
                        Removable devices that provide support and posture correction cues for a client with traumatic brain injury while performing gait training therapy on a treadmill.
                        Team: Change of Pace 
                              Meredith Clouse
                              Amanda Jacobson
 
                        Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.
 

11:05 a.m.       iHorse Simulator
                        A device that simulates the hip motion and core muscle activity experienced when an individual rides a horse, for easier equine-assisted therapy.
                        Team: RMS Able
                              Melissa Montgomery
                              Nicole Richardson
                              Jaqueline Simon
                        Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.
 

11:21 a.m.       Locker Independence
                        A discreet device that allows students with disabilities to independently and easily open their lockers at school.
                        Team: Open Sesame
                              Ben Deschaine
                              Andrew May
                              Michael Petro
                        Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.
 

11:37 a.m.       Break
                                Refreshments provided by the Department of Applied Biology and Biomedical Engineering.
 

11:52 a.m.       Large Image Board Communication Device
                        A device that a client with cerebral palsy can use to better communicate with the people around her.
                        Team: Daedalus
                              James Grinnell
                              Kevin Weaver
 
                                Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.
                        

12:08 p.m.       Therapeutic Saddle
                        A saddle that provides back, hand, and leg support for riders participating in equine-assisted therapy.
                        Team: Supporting Saddles
                              Michael Boyer
                              Peter Moorman
                              Candice Sandberg
                                Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.
 

12:34 p.m.       Music Therapy Device
                        A device that allows a person who is blind and has limited motor skills to express his emotions through music. 
                        Team: Airily Hew
                              Whitney Baenziger
                              Erin Davey
                              Alyse Mueller
                                Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.
 

12:24 p.m.       Walker with Detachable Table
                        A device to support a young client with cerebral palsy during his frequent seizures, yet also assist his mobility and muscle development.
                        Team: Kid Kinetics
                              Kasie Anderson
                              Neil Dorsey
                              Glen Janson
                              Maggie Schultz
                                Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.
 

12:40 p.m.       Japanese Home Mobility Device
                        A device that allows a client in Japan who must remain in a reclining position to move freely and independently around her home.
                        Team: International Navigators
                              Michael Johnson
                              Travis Stallings
                              Devon Trumbauer
                        Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.

12:56 p.m.       Moveable Island.............................................................................................. 29-30
                        A device that improves kitchen safety and accessibility for a client with dwarfism.
                        Special thanks to this team’s local client.
                        Team: Top Chef
                              Betsy Jones
                              Anna Lewer
                              Travis Nong 
                                Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.

Title: Chemistry and Biochemistry Seminar
Body:
Faraday Rotation and Raman Spectroscopy 
of Aqueous Solutions of Ferric Salts.
 
Max Verkamp
Dr. Maarij Syed, PHOE
Dr. Daniel Morris, C&BC
 
Wednesday, March 27
5th period, 11:45 a.m.
Room G315
Faraday Rotation, the rotation of light induced in transparent media by a magnetic field, is a phenomenon commonly used in optical systems.  In this presentation, the application of this technique to chemical systems as a probe of magnetic properties of aqueous iron(III) solutions will be investigated.  The theory of Faraday Rotation will be discussed, followed by a description of the current research and results.  By measuring the rotation of solutions at varying magnetic field strength using a carefully designed optical system with a lock-in amplifier, a material property, the Verdet constant, can be determined.
 
In the present work, ferric chloride and ferric nitrate solutions were prepared at several concentrations, limited at 2.0 M by solubility considerations.  The effect of additional chloride ion on the ferric chloride system was investigated using ferric chloride solutions made with set concentrations of sodium chloride.  A plot of the concentration dependence of the Verdet constant revealed a linear response for ferric nitrate and a non-linear response for ferric chloride.  The non-linearity became more pronounced with additional chloride ion present in solution.  Raman spectra were obtained for all solutions to examine aqueous iron(III) speciation as a possible explanation for the non-linear behavior.

Body:

In the present work, ferric chloride and ferric nitrate solutions were prepared at several concentrations, limited at 2.0 M by solubility considerations.  The effect of additional chloride ion on the ferric chloride system was investigated using ferric chloride solutions made with set concentrations of sodium chloride.  A plot of the concentration dependence of the Verdet constant revealed a linear response for ferric nitrate and a non-linear response for ferric chloride.  The non-linearity became more pronounced with additional chloride ion present in solution.  Raman spectra were obtained for all solutions to examine aqueous iron(III) speciation as a possible explanation for the non-linear behavior.

Student Organization Presidents,

To register your organization, you will need to complete the following:

Title: Reminder: Biomedical Engineering Seniors to present their design projects Wednesday, March 27th
Body:
The Biomedical Engineering senior class will be presenting their capstone design projects Wednesday, March 27, in room E104, from 9:40 a.m. to 1:35 p.m. Everyone is welcome to attend any or all of the presentations – details below!
9:40 a.m. Welcome


9:45 a.m. The Stable-izer
A device to be used in equine-assisted therapy that detects when the rider of a horse is leaning away from the vertical position and sounds an alert when the rider needs assistance to correct his or her posture.
Team: Genuine Risk Engineering
Creasy Clauser
Tanya Colonna
Alex Schwier
Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.


10:01 a.m....... Cornstarch Dispensing System
A device to allow persons with cognitive and/or physical disabilities to more easily and neatly complete the employment task of filling small bags with cornstarch.
Team: BEC Engineering
Emily Lakes
Carley Shumate
Brianne Widmoyer

Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.


10:17 a.m....... Leg Brace Redesign
A leg brace with a flexible knee joint that will allow a person with post-polio syndrome to walk with an improved gait cycle.
Team: Brace Yourself
Stephen Kays
Nick Pilipovich
Mac White
Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.


10:33 a.m. Bowling Ball for Individuals with Disabilities
A bowling ball designed for use by individuals with low grip strength and/or neuromuscular control.
Team: The Perfect Game
Sam Brooks
Adam Dills

Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.


10:49 a.m. Treadmill Modifications
Removable devices that provide support and posture correction cues for a client with traumatic brain injury while performing gait training therapy on a treadmill.
Team: Change of Pace 
Meredith Clouse
Amanda Jacobson

Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.


11:05 a.m. iHorse Simulator
A device that simulates the hip motion and core muscle activity experienced when an individual rides a horse, for easier equine-assisted therapy.
Team: RMS Able
Melissa Montgomery
Nicole Richardson
Jaqueline Simon
Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.


11:21 a.m. Locker Independence
A discreet device that allows students with disabilities to independently and easily open their lockers at school.
Team: Open Sesame
Ben Deschaine
Andrew May
Michael Petro
Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.


11:37 a.m. Break
Refreshments provided by the Department of Applied Biology and Biomedical Engineering.


11:52 a.m. Large Image Board Communication Device
A device that a client with cerebral palsy can use to better communicate with the people around her.
Team: Daedalus
James Grinnell
Kevin Weaver

Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.


12:08 p.m. Therapeutic Saddle
A saddle that provides back, hand, and leg support for riders participating in equine-assisted therapy.
Team: Supporting Saddles
Michael Boyer
Peter Moorman
Candice Sandberg
Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.


12:34 p.m. Music Therapy Device
A device that allows a person who is blind and has limited motor skills to express his emotions through music. 
Team: Airily Hew
Whitney Baenziger
Erin Davey
Alyse Mueller
Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.


12:24 p.m. Walker with Detachable Table
A device to support a young client with cerebral palsy during his frequent seizures, yet also assist his mobility and muscle development.
Team: Kid Kinetics
Kasie Anderson
Neil Dorsey
Glen Janson
Maggie Schultz
Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.


12:40 p.m. Japanese Home Mobility Device
A device that allows a client in Japan who must remain in a reclining position to move freely and independently around her home.
Team: International Navigators
Michael Johnson
Travis Stallings
Devon Trumbauer
Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.

12:56 p.m. Moveable Island.............................................................................................. 29-30
A device that improves kitchen safety and accessibility for a client with dwarfism.
Special thanks to this team’s local client.
Team: Top Chef
Betsy Jones
Anna Lewer
Travis Nong 
Funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation.

Title: Reminder: SimplyWell Speaker - Tax-Smart Ways to Save and Invest - TODAY
Body:
Tax-Smart Ways to Save and Invest
Wednesday, March 27, 2013
10:50 – 11:40 a.m. OR 1:35 – 2:35 p.m.
HMU – Heritage Room

Presenter
Erin Robertson, TIAA-CREF
 

Take three important steps to identify potential areas for saving money:
1. Reduce the taxes you pay on earnings.
2. Reduce the amount you spend.
3. Make ‘tax-smart’ choices to keep more of what you earn.
 

We’ll discuss:
· Effective withholding strategies
· Tax-favored financial products
· Roth and Traditional IRAs
· Basic investment strategies

To sign up, please log on to ANGEL and choose ROSExperience. Spouses are welcome to attend this event! Space is limited.
SimplyWell participants may earn 250 points under the Wellness Events category. Please log on to SimplyWell's website and enter your points within 90 days of this session.
If you have any questions, please contact Pam Pahnke at ext. 8916.

Body:

If you have any questions, please contact me: richarsm@rose-hulman.edu or Dr. Shillingford: shilling@rose-hulman.edu

Title: IM Strongest Engineer Competition Registration
Body:
* Registration for the IM Strongest Engineer Competition begins today! Please log onto www.imleagues.com to register for this event. The registration deadline is Wednesday, April 17th and the event will take place on Sunday, April 21st in the SRC Fieldhouse. Come out and see if you are RHIT's Strongest Engineer for your weight class!




5th Annual IM Strongest Engineer Comp.

Who: Open to all Rose-Hulman students, faculty and staff. Male and female participation are both strongly encouraged!!! There will be a Greek, Residence Hall, and Independent Champion for each division for both males and females.

What: 5th Annual Intramural Strongest Engineer Competition!!!

When: The registration deadline is Wednesday, April 17th. Please log onto www.imleagues.com to register. Make sure to register for the correct weight class. The competition will take place on Sunday, April 21st starting at 1pm.

Where: Please meet in the Sports and Recreation Center Fieldhouse to go over rules. The majority of the competition will take place on the fieldhouse courts.

Why: Prove to the campus that you are THE STRONGEST ENGINEER (in your weight class)!!! Also, IM points will be awarded to the winning Residence Hall, Greek, and Independent participants towards the Intramural All Sports Championship. The overall winner for each division will be awarded 5 points and given the choice of awards (either t-shirt or mug).

Costs: FREE!!!

Additional Information: The Intramural Strongest Engineer Competition rules are attached to this posting. Rules and more details are also available in the Intramural Office (SRC 265 D) and will be posted on the IM webpage www.rose-hulman.edu/Intramurals/IM_Classic. If you have any questions or concerns about the competition, please contact Dan O'Leary at ext. 8987 or oleary2@rose-hulman.edu . 

Events and Rules: Each athlete will have up to 3 attempts at each event (except for the tug of war competition). All athletes take their first attempt, the order will then rotate through again for the second attempt, and finally the third attempt. If an athlete is satisfied with their score, they may choose to not make an attempt. But, if they do not make a second attempt, they are not allowed to try again for the third. The athlete's highest score of the 3 will be the one that is counted for record.

Gator Pull: The contestant, wearing a harness attached to the gator, will pull the gator with an IM staff member sitting in the driver seat facing the direction of the finish line throughout the pull. The winner is the contestant who completes the course in the fastest time.

Tire Flip: Contestants will try and flip a tractor tire (or comparable object) as many times as possible in one minute. The contestant flipping the tire the most is the winner.

Farmer's Walk: Contestant will carry a weight in each hand over a marked course in as quick time as possible.

1 vs. 1 Tug of War: One on one tug of war competition is a single elimination tournament. The winner from each match will advance until a champion has been determined.

Atlas Stones: Contestants will have to place 5 heavy "stones" increasing in weight and height on a platform.
 
Thanks,
Dan O'Leary
Coordinator for Intramurals, 
Club Sports and Special Events
PHONE:    812-877-8987
CELL:        812-201-7903

Title: Chemical Engineering Graduate Seminar
Body:
“Project Safety Management: An Introduction to What Chemical Engineers Need to Know”
 
Speaker: Rory Chambers
Project Safety Manager, SgSolutions
 
Date:  Friday, April 19, 2013
Time:  2:30 pm (8th period)
Place:  Room O267
 
Abstract:
 
This presentation will provide an overview of the OSHA and EPA regulations that many Chemical Engineering students will interact with throughout their careers in the Chemical/Petro-Chemical industries.  In addition to a historical review of why the regulations exist and their general scope a more thorough review of the three sections that new employees will be expected to interact with will be included.  This more in-depth review will cover: Process Hazard Analysis, Management of Change and Pre-Start Up Safety Reviews.  Through the use of specific examples based on industrial experience attendees will gain an insight that will allow them to better understand the regulatory nomenclature that they will face when entering the job market.
 
Refreshments will be provided!

Title: Open Enrollment Information Session - Tuesday, April 23, 2013
Body:
Open Enrollment Information Session
Tuesday, April 23, 2013
 
8:00 - 9:00 a.m. 
 
OR
 
6:00 - 7:00 p.m.

Title: Registration Deadline for IM Strongest Engineer is Today!
Body:
* Registration deadline for the IM Strongest Engineer Competition is today! 
 
Please log onto www.imleagues.com to register for this event. The registration deadline is Wednesday, April 17th and the event will take place on Sunday, April 21st in the SRC Fieldhouse. Come out and see if you are RHIT's Strongest Engineer for your weight class!




5th Annual IM Strongest Engineer Comp.

Who: Open to all Rose-Hulman students, faculty and staff. Male and female participation are both strongly encouraged!!! There will be a Greek, Residence Hall, and Independent Champion for each division for both males and females.

What: 5th Annual Intramural Strongest Engineer Competition!!!

When: The registration deadline is Wednesday, April 17th. Please log onto www.imleagues.com to register. Make sure to register for the correct weight class. The competition will take place on Sunday, April 21st starting at 1pm.

Where: Please meet in the Sports and Recreation Center Fieldhouse to go over rules. The majority of the competition will take place on the fieldhouse courts.

Why: Prove to the campus that you are THE STRONGEST ENGINEER (in your weight class)!!! Also, IM points will be awarded to the winning Residence Hall, Greek, and Independent participants towards the Intramural All Sports Championship. The overall winner for each division will be awarded 5 points and given the choice of awards (either t-shirt or mug).

Costs: FREE!!!

Additional Information: The Intramural Strongest Engineer Competition rules are attached to this posting. Rules and more details are also available in the Intramural Office (SRC 265 D) and will be posted on the IM webpage www.rose-hulman.edu/Intramurals/IM_Classic. If you have any questions or concerns about the competition, please contact Dan O'Leary at ext. 8987 or oleary2@rose-hulman.edu . 

Events and Rules: Each athlete will have up to 3 attempts at each event (except for the tug of war competition). All athletes take their first attempt, the order will then rotate through again for the second attempt, and finally the third attempt. If an athlete is satisfied with their score, they may choose to not make an attempt. But, if they do not make a second attempt, they are not allowed to try again for the third. The athlete's highest score of the 3 will be the one that is counted for record.

Gator Pull: The contestant, wearing a harness attached to the gator, will pull the gator with an IM staff member sitting in the driver seat facing the direction of the finish line throughout the pull. The winner is the contestant who completes the course in the fastest time.

Tire Flip: Contestants will try and flip a tractor tire (or comparable object) as many times as possible in one minute. The contestant flipping the tire the most is the winner.

Farmer's Walk: Contestant will carry a weight in each hand over a marked course in as quick time as possible.

1 vs. 1 Tug of War: One on one tug of war competition is a single elimination tournament. The winner from each match will advance until a champion has been determined.

Atlas Stones: Contestants will have to place 5 heavy "stones" increasing in weight and height on a platform.

 
Thanks,
 
Dan O'Leary
Coordinator for Intramurals, 
Club Sports and Special Events
PHONE: 812-877-8987
CELL: 812-201-7903

Title: Chemistry and Biochemistry Seminar
Body:
Development of a Fluorescent Assay for Estrogen Receptor β

                                      Alex Krug

                                Wednesday, April 24
                                  5th period, 11:45
                                         G315

	One in every eight American women will develop breast cancer throughout the course of her lifetime. As such it is one the leading causes of death for women in first world countries. The current forms of hormone therapy for breast cancer have a number of undesirable side effects, including menopausal symptoms and possible development of uterine cancer. The current question plaguing modern medicine is the mechanism for these side effects and how they arise. How can a drug that clearly blocks estrogen activity in the breast, activate estrogen activity in other tissues?

	One hypothesis is that another estrogen receptor subtype, known as estrogen receptor beta, is the cause. The role of ER beta in healthy and cancerous cells is still a mystery, so specific probing of the role of the receptor is essential. Key components of these investigations are a purified receptor for in vitro studies and a method for determining the binding affinity of known and novel drugs to this receptor. In the current state of pharmacology, radioactive and fluorescent based assays are commonly used. The goal of this research is to develop a method to produce the human form of ER beta in bacteria and then establish a protocol to analyze a drug’s efficacy on estrogen receptor β using fluorescence polarization.

Title: IM Track and Field Meet is Wednesday
Body:
* The IM Track & Field Meet will be held on Wednesday, April 24th starting at 6:00pm. There is no need to pre-register, just arrive on the day of the event to the outdoor track from 5pm - 5:45pm for field events and from 5:00pm - 6:30pm for running events. If you have any questions or concerns, please contact Dan O'Leary at oleary2@rose-hulman.edu or ext. 8987. 
 



2013 Intramural Track & Field Meet Information

Who: Open to all Rose-Hulman students (not 2012-2013 Rose-Hulman Track & Field team members), faculty, and staff. Male and female participation are both strongly encouraged!!! We will have both a Male and Female Champion for each event and division; Greek, Residence Hall, and Independent.

What: Intramural Track & Field Meet. There will be 9 different events.

When: The meet will be on Wednesday, April 24th starting at 6:00pm. There is no need to pre-register. Participants will register the day of the event at the outdoor track from 5:00pm - 5:45pm for field events and from 5:00pm - 6:30pm for running events.

Where: William Welch Outdoor Track & Field Complex, which is located in Cook Stadium.

Why: Intramural points will be awarded to the winning Residence Hall, Greek, and Independent participants towards the Intramural All Sports Championship (2 points for a first place finish). Also, the overall winning Residence Hall, Greek, and Independent team will receive 15 points. Awards will also be given to the winners (either a mug or t-shirt).

Additional Information: Below you will find the order of events for the Intramural Track & Field Meet. Also, attached to this posting is more information concerning the rules and regulations for the meet. You can find IM Track & Field information on the IM webpage www.rose-hulman.edu/Intramurals/IM_Classic. If you have any questions or concerns, please contact Dan O'Leary at ext. 8987 or at oleary2@rose-hulman.edu. Thanks and have a great day!!!
 


Order of Intramural Track & Field Meet Events 

5:30pm Warm-ups Begin 
6:00pm Field Events Begin
· Softball Toss
· Long Jump
· High Jump
6:45pm Track Events Begin (Women/ Men)
Order of events are:
· 4 X 100 Meter Relay
· 800 Meter 
· 100 Meter
· 4 X 200 Meter Relay
· 1600 Meter
· 4 X 400 Meter Relay
8:00pm Estimated Conclusion


Scoring system for each event

Place Points
1st 10
2nd 8
3rd 6
4th 4 
5th 2
6th 1


15 points will be awarded to the champions of the Greek, Independent, and Residence Hall teams. The above scoring system (1st through 6th place) is to determine the overall winner for each Greek, Independent, and Residence Hall. Once the overall winners for Greek, Independent, and Residence Hall are determined, the appropriate teams will then be awarded the 15 points to count toward the 2012-2013 overall point champions.

2 individual points will be awarded per event for 1st place finishes. These points will count toward the 2012-2013 overall point champions.

Body:
* The IM Golf Scramble registration begins today, Monday, April 22nd. Please log onto www.imleagues.com and register your team by the May 1st registration deadline. The scramble will take place on Saturday, May 4th starting @ 1pm at Mark's Par 3. The fee is $20 per team, which is due to Dan O'Leary in SRC Office 265 D or CM 37 by the registration deadline. If you have any questions or concerns, please contact Dan O'Leary at oleary2@rose-hulman.edu. Thanks and good luck in the scramble!!!
 



 

Intramural Golf Scramble
 

Who: Open to all Rose-Hulman students (not Rose-Hulman golf team members), faculty, and staff. Both male and female participation are strongly encouraged!!! There will be a separate champion based on gender and division (Greek, Res Hall, Independent). Coed teams are also allowed.
 

What: 2013 Spring Intramural Golf Scramble, which will be held on Saturday, May 4th starting at 1pm. Teams must consists of 4 players (can only take the first 18 teams). Play by scramble rules, which is playing the team's best shot. Thus, each team will turn in only once score for the scramble.
 

When: Registration begins Monday, April 16th. The registration deadline is Wednesday, April 25th. Please log onto www.imleagues.com to register your team. The golf scramble will be held on Saturday, April 28th starting at 1pm.
 

Where: Mark's Par Three Golf Course, which is located at 2401 N. Chamberlain Street, just east of campus in Seelyville.

 
Why: Intramural points (15 pts) will be awarded to the winning Greek, Independent, and Residence Hall teams towards the Intramural All Sports Championship. Also, we will be having hole challenges; closest to the pin, longest putt, longest drive, etc.... Awards will be given to the team scramble and challenge winners.

 
Cost: An entry fee of $5.00 per player ($20.00 per team) is required before the end of the registration deadline. Please register online at www.imleagues.com, but submit your payment to Dan O'Leary at SRC Office 265 D or CM 37. Payments may be made in the form of cash or check, payable to Rose-Hulman Intramurals. Carts will be available upon request at the golf course for an extra charge (pay at golf course).
 
Thanks,
 
Dan O'Leary
Coordinator for Intramurals, 
Club Sports and Special Events
PHONE:    812-877-8987
CELL:        812-201-79035500 WABASH AVENUE   CM 37
TERRE HAUTE, IN  47803-3920
www.rose-hulman.edu

Title: Custom PC Building
Body:
Ever want a desktop computer? Want that computer to have name brand performance but not pay name brand price? (i.e. Dell, HP, Alienware, etc.) I have the solution for you! I do custom PC building! Custom PCs are the better option because you get exactly the performance you need/want at a price much more affordable and competitive than Dells, Apples, or HPs. Custom PCs can be built for basic computing, web browsing, and document editing or for high-performance media editing, high-definition gaming, or media storage, or anything in between! If you're curious and want to know more information let me know. I offer custom PC building for cost of parts + some commission. All prices can be negotiated. 

Here is a link to my personal rig so you can see an example of my work: http://imgur.com/soX2UCa 

tubbcc@rose-hulman.edu

Thanks for your time!

Title: Pond Management Workshop
Body:
Purdue Extension and Vigo County Parks Department will provide information on a variety of topics relating to pond and lake management.

Thursday, April 25th 5:30-7:30pm at Fowler Park in Vigo County. 

This workshop will address concerns relating to aeration, pond weed control, and maintenance. This free workshop will take place rain or shine at the lake at Fowler Park.  Aquatic weed control specialist Keith Ruble will address weed identification concerns, so bring your favorite pond weeds in a bucket.

Fowler Park is located 7.2 miles south of I-70 on US 41, and 0.8 miles east on Oregon Church Road.

No pre-registration is required. For more information contact Jim Luzar of Purdue Extension Vigo County at 812-462-3371 or e-mail luzar@purdue.edu.

Title: Registration Deadline for IM Disc Golf is Today!
Body:
* Registration deadline for the IM Disc Golf Tournament is today.
 
Please log onto www.imleagues.com to register your team. The registration deadline is Wednesday, Aptil 24th and the tournament will take place on Saturday, April 27th starting at 1pm at Deming Park. If you have any questions, please e-mail Dan O'Leary at oleary2@rose-hulman.edu. 
 



 


IM Disc Golf Tournament
 

Who: Open to all students, faculty and staff. We will have male and female winners for all divisions (greek, res hall, independent). We can only accept the first 36 teams to register (teams of 2).

 
What: Intramural Disc Golf Tournament. 18-hole tournament played with teams of 2 (scramble style). 

 
When: Registration begins today, Monday, April 15th. The registration deadline is Wednesday, April 24th. Please be sure to register your team on www.imleagues.com before the registration deadline. The tournament will be held on Saturday, April 27th starting at 1pm.

 
Where: The tournament will be played at Deming Park's disc golf course. We will meet at hole #1 tee box.

 
Why: It will be a fun event, which you can win either an IM champ t-shirt or IM champ mug. Also, winners can earn points for their affiliation towards the overall IM point standings. 

 
Costs: FREE!!!

 
Additional Information: A copy of the IM Disc Golf Tournament rules are attached to this posting. You will also be able to find a copy of the rules on the IM webpage www.rose-hulman.edu/Intramurals/IM_Classic. Please register early to assure your spot in the tournament. We can only accept the first 36 teams who register on IMLeagues. If you have any problems registering, or if you have any questions or concerns, please contact Dan O'Leary at ext. 8987 or oleary2@rose-hulman.edu. 
 
Thanks!
 

Dan O'Leary
Coordinator for Intramurals, 
Club Sports and Special Events
