Title: Selling Percopo Loft
Body:
Hey!
If you are living in Percopo next year and are interested in a very sturdy loft, you should get in contact with us! 
We have a loft for sale!
It is about 6 ft tall so you are able to stand comfortable underneath. We placed our beds on top and were able to sit up in them. The loft fills the back half of the room, but you are able to fit your desks and the dresser underneath and still have lots of space to walk around. 
We are asking for 200 dollars (which is what we paid for it). The loft is in excellent condition and isn’t too hard to put up. 1
Contact me if you would like pictures or to come see it. 
Please email me at jaysr@rose-hulman.edu

Title: Selling 24" Monitor
Body: Selling an Asus VW246H because I've bought a newer screen and I don't use this one anymore. Asking $40 OBO. You can contact me at tugayac@rose-hulman.edu if interested. The monitor has served me well and it's good for all around use. I used it for gaming and schoolwork. It has a 2ms response time, 20000:1 Contrast Ratio, 1 HDMI, 1 VGA, 1 DVI input, as well as built-in speakers. Comes with Power Cable and DVI-I cable. DisplayPort to DVI converters can be bought for cheap on Amazon.com. Thank you!

Title: Team Rose Motorsports seeks Sponsor for AutoX
Body:
Hi everybody,
We (Team Rose Motorsports) are looking to go to an autocross THIS Saturday, May 17th 2014. The event is in Rantoul, IL. It is about an hour and a half away from Terre Haute. We typically leave Terre Haute around 8am and return around 6:30pm. Anyways, we need a sponsor (such as a professor) to accompany us to allow us to bring team cars with us. So, if you are interested, or don't have other plans, or just want to go fast, let me know! 


Kyle Burrell
Vice President of Team Rose Motorsports
Contact: burrelks@rose-hulman.edu

Title: Learn at Lunch Opportunity: Downtown Terre Haute, Inc. - Wednesday, May 21, 2014
Body:
Downtown Terre Haute, Inc.





Wednesday, May 21, 2014
11:45 a.m. - 12:35 p.m.



HMU – Heritage Room
 




Presenter: Shelley Klingerman, Executive Director, Downtown Terre Haute, Inc. 






Downtown Terre Haute, Inc. is an organization that promotes merchants, events, and projects happening in downtown Terre Haute. 
The summertime will prove to be an exciting time for downtown Terre Haute with all kinds of events for the whole family. Shelley will discuss Downtown Terre Haute, Inc. and what visitors can expect when visiting downtown Terre Haute this summer. 











Please register by logging in to ANGEL and clicking on ROSExperience.

Title: Discovery of Delta-Scuti Stars of the F3V Spectral Type
Body:
Brian G. Kodalen
Senior Physics/Math
Department of Physics and Optical Engineering
 
 
*The Department of Physics and Optical Engineering is pleased to announce that Brian Kodalen (Thesis Advisor:  Dr. Richard Ditteon) will give a presentation on his senior thesis in Myers 137 beginning at 3:25 p.m. on Tuesday, May 20, 2014.  
 
Tuesday, May 20, 2014
Beginning at 3:25 p.m.
Myers 137
 
 
Abstract
Discovery of Delta-Scuti Stars of the F3V Spectral Type
 
            We can observe many stars in our sky which change in their brightness over time. Some Main-Sequence stars which intersect the instability strip vary over periods as small as a few hours. During the winter last year, I observed 43 stars of the F3V spectral type in order to determine how many would show Delta-Scuti variability. During this talk, I will discuss what we expect from Delta-Scuti stars as well as the various methods used to process these observations into usable images. I will then show how we can use these images to create light curves, giving us an indication of the variability of the stars observed.
 
 
Refreshments served.

Title: Selling high end gaming computer
Body:
I don't really wanna deal with transporting it, so i'm selling my rig. Maxes out most games at 1080p at 60fps, runs quiet. Everything else is extremely snappy and responsive. I'll be dusting out and formatting everything before selling, of course. You can check it and see how games like Crysis 3 run before you buy in deming 020. No peripherals included, monitor optional.

700$ OBO
 
Specs:
-Intel I5 3570k
-asrock z77 pro 4
-coolermaster hyper 212+
-8gb ripjaws ram
-60gb mushkin chronos solid state drive
-500gb caviar black hard drive
-nzxt 650w semimodular hale82 (seasonic OEM)
-powercolor AX7950 (nonreference model for those interested)
-corsair 300r
-2x cougar vortexes

i'll throw in a benq XL2420T 120hz monitor for another 240$, they retailed for 300. it's still in excellent condition and i still have the box. 120hz monitors are extremely fluid compared to normal 60hz monitors and my graphics card can drive 120hz in a lot of games, though you might have to turn down the graphics to high in recent titles if you want to get the most out of it.

I will then show how we can use these images to create light curves, giving us an indication of the variability of the stars observed.
 
 
Refreshments served.

Title: Learn at Lunch Opportunity: Downtown Terre Haute, Inc. - Today
Body:
Downtown Terre Haute, Inc.





Wednesday, May 21, 2014
11:45 a.m. - 12:35 p.m.



HMU – Heritage Room
 





Presenter: Shelley Klingerman, Executive Director, Downtown Terre Haute, Inc. 






Downtown Terre Haute, Inc. is an organization that promotes merchants, events, and projects happening in downtown Terre Haute. 
The summertime will prove to be an exciting time for downtown Terre Haute with all kinds of events for the whole family. Shelley will discuss Downtown Terre Haute, Inc. and what visitors can expect when visiting downtown Terre Haute this summer. 











Please register by logging in to ANGEL and clicking on ROSExperience.

Title: Engineering of Semiconductor Devices
Body:
Mr. Tom Welch
Fairchild Semiconductor
Salt Lake City, Utah
 
 
*The Department of Physics and Optical Engineering is pleased to announce that Mr. Tom Welch will give a presentation in GM Room beginning at 1:35 p.m. on Friday, May 23, 2014.  
 
Friday, May 23, 2014
Beginning at 1:35 p.m.
GM Room
 
 
Abstract
Engineering of Semiconductor Devices
 
Tom Welch has worked as an engineer in the semiconductor industry of Silicon Valley for the past fifty years.  He is presently the Principal Engineer of Fairchild Semiconductor’s SPG Group in Salt Lake, Utah.  Previous posts at Fairchild in the last ten years include Director of Quality and Failure Analysis and Director of Engineering Discrete Products.  Further back he has been a plant manager and process engineer.  Semiconductor Engineering has taken Mr. Welch all over the world including extensive stays in Algeria, Philippines, Malaysia, China, Japan, Taiwan and others.  In this talk he will describe his own experiences in the rapidly developing semiconductor industry from the 1960s to the present.
 
Mr. Welch’s education includes a year at Rose-Hulman in the 1960s.
 
Mr. Welch will answer questions and give advice to students considering a career in the semiconductor industry today.
 
            
 
Refreshments served.

Title: Cat looking for FOREVER home
Body: Lovely, nice, in-house cat looking for a new home. Female, age unknown, but very sweet. You can keep rubbing her belly for 5 min without getting hurt!! (it's amazing for a cat, right?!) She is very quiet, and love to stick with humans, but acts very shy at the beginning, so give her time to adjust. She also eats Grain Free cat food. You can also get a water fountain w/ new filters, cat litter box, hair brush, and a bottle of cat shampoo(although she hates water :3) for free.If you want to give her a name and home to stay forever, please e-mail me. hey1@rose-hulman.edu Photo attached.

Title: Apartment Stuff for Sale
Body:
My roommates and I are leaving our apartment at VQ and have some furniture for sale if anyone is interested feel free to send me an email or call me. Also most of this furniture is only one year old. FYI: we are wanting to be completely moved out by May 31 and would possibly be able to help move the stuff. Listed below is everything we have for sale with the price listed next to it. Know that prices may be negotiable.

-2 office desks: $150 for one $100 for other
-1 dresser drawer: $75
-Shelving: all combined $75
-1 Leather Sofa: $100
-3 Love Seats: $75 for each
-1 wood bar w/ finished countertop : $150 (in our case this worked out better than having a large table because you can do school work and still have fun)
-TV/Entertainment stand: $25
-4 Lamps: $50 ( you will need these if you plan on living in an apartment just because most apartments have limited overhead lighting especially in    bedrooms)
-2 bar stools: $25 
-Side table: $25

Feel free to contact my roommate Alex Pohl
pohlag@rose-hulman.edu
317-525-0270

Title: Selling HDMI adapters
Body:
Frustrated that your laptop doesn’t have an HDMI output?
 
Get set for summer! I have a number of laptop HDMI adapters (miniDP->HDMI and DP->HDMI) and HDMI cables for sale. These allow you to connect your laptop to any HD TV, carrying both video and audio.
 
Here’s what I have:
- 8-inch miniDP to HDMI adapter (for "Freshman" and “Sophomore” Lenovo W530) - $10
- DP to HDMI adapter (for "Junior” Lenovo W520 and "Senior" Lenovo W510) - $10
- 6-ft HDMI cord - $5
 
If you don't already have an HDMI cord, you'll need both the adapter and cord. If you already have an HDMI cord to use, all you need to buy is the adapter.

 
Please email Ethan Skinner at skinneet@rose-hulman.edu

Title: FS: Mac Mini

Title: SimplyWell Opportunity: Walk Around Campus - Wednesday, June 4, 2014
Body:
SimplyWell Session
Walk Around Campus
 

Wednesday, June 4, 2014
9:00 a.m. or 3:00 p.m.
Meet at Hadley Hall Circle
 

Please join us at 9:00 a.m. or 3:00 p.m. as we walk around our beautiful campus. Please wear comfortable shoes. Pace is not as important as the goal to get some exercise. Walk with the group or go at your own pace as needed.
 

If the weather is not appropriate for walking outside, we will walk in the academic buildings. 
 

Please register by visiting ANGEL and click on ROSExperience.
 

Spouses are welcome to attend. Please register a spouse by contacting Pamela Pahnke. 
 


SimplyWell participants can earn 250 points for each session attended. Please record your points on SimplyWell's website on/before June 15th.

Title: SimplyWell Session: Importance of Annual Exams - Tuesday, June 10
Body:
SimplyWell Session
The Importance of Annual Exams
 


Tuesday, June 10, 2014
12:00 - 1:00 p.m.
HMU - Noble Romans/Worx
Presenter: RHIT Health Services
 



Please bring your lunch and join us as Dr. Mark Schuld and Mary Davidson, Nurse Practitioner, present on the importance of annual exams and tests such as colonoscopies and mammograms.
 
 
Please register by visiting ANGEL and click on ROSExperience.
 
Spouses are welcome to attend. Please register a spouse by contacting Pamela Pahnke. 
 
SimplyWell participants can earn 250 points for attending this session. Please record your points on SimplyWell's website on/before June 15th.

Title: Airport Ride (6/1) Urgently Requested from Pretty Great Person
Body:
What: I'd like a ride to the Indianapolis Airport.
When: We'd leave at 11:30 am or earlier on Sunday (June 1st), providing ample time before my flight at 2:55 pm.
How: With company that can talk to you the entire drive and just as easily be silent for it. I can look up jokes if you want and read them out to you for entertainment, really whatever.
Where: I'm currently on campus so I can meet you anywhere here.
Why: Gas reimbursement and I can pay for lunch if you want too, plus adventure! Would you turn down adventure??


To all who can't provide me a ride, have a great summer break!
To all who can, the same to you and PLEASE.

Title: SimplyWell Opportunity: Walk Around Campus - Wednesday, June 4, 2014
Body:
SimplyWell Session
Walk Around Campus
 


Wednesday, June 4, 2014
9:00 a.m. or 3:00 p.m.
Meet at Hadley Hall Circle
 


Do you need to attend wellness events for SimplyWell points before the June 15th deadline? If so, please join us at 9:00 a.m. or 3:00 p.m. as we walk around our beautiful campus. Please wear comfortable shoes. Pace is not as important as the goal to get some exercise. Walk with the group or go at your own pace as needed.
 


If the weather is not appropriate for walking outside, we will walk in the academic buildings. 
 


Please register by visiting ANGEL and click on ROSExperience.
 


Spouses are welcome to attend. Please register a spouse by contacting Pamela Pahnke. 
 



SimplyWell participants can earn 250 points for each session attended. Please record your points on SimplyWell's website on/before June 15th.

Title: Looking For ECE for assistance designing PCB and using Eagle
Body:
We are in need of having a few pcbs designed and made. Being ME's we are looking to find someone who has experience prototyping pcbs and circuit design. If you would like to make some extra cash and have relevant experience let us know. Being proficient with Eagle is a must.

Our first job is very simple, you will need to take mechanical data (dxf output) and lay it out in eagle format so that we can send it to the fab shop. If this is done well and after some development there will be some more substantial jobs for you.

If interested, send me an email at kenneybc@rose-hulman.edu and give us a good reason to give you the job.

Title: Learn at Lunch Session: Book Review and Signing - Thursday, July 17, 2014
Body:
Learn at Lunch Session
Book Review and Signing 
 
Thursday, July 17, 2014
11:45 a.m. - 12:35 p.m.
HMU - Heritage Room
 
Speaker: Mike Lunsford
 

Mike Lunsford is a teacher and writer from rural southern Parke County. His human interest column, “The Off Season,” is regularly published in the Terre Haute Tribune-Star, and his newest collection of stories, A Windy Hill Almanac was released in late October, 2013. Mike works out of his writer’s cabin, the result of his receiving an Eli Lilly Teacher Creativity Grant in 2010. 
A teacher of English and American History in Southwest Parke Community Schools for 35 years, he was named the Indiana Rural School Teacher of the Year in 2009, was in the inaugural class of the Abraham Lincoln Teacher Fellowship Program at the Lincoln Presidential Library in 2006, won an Arts-Illiana Bravo Award for Arts Advocacy in 2005, was named the Indiana History Teacher of the Year in 2003, and was a WTHI-TV10 Golden Apple winner in 1998. He has been named Reader’s Choice “Best Columnist" in both 2011 and 2013.

 Mike will be discussing his newest book, A Windy Hill Almanac, and will be participating in a book signing. 
Books will be available for purchase on/after July 7 in Human Resources. 



Please register by visiting the following link: http://rosestem.rose-hulman.edu/lal0714
 
 



Spouses are welcome to attend and can register at the link above.

Title: whole turkeys for sale
Body:
Whole turkeys available starting July 10; delivery to your home/office included, date/time arranged at your convenience. Ethically raised on fresh grass and plenty of sunshine. $3 per pound, average size 16-20 pounds. Pay on delivery. Email ingram@rose-hulman.edu to reserve yours now.

Why buy a turkey in July? 
Cooking a whole turkey heats the kitchen once but yields multiple meals (enchiladas, turkey noodle casserole, etc.). Having a turkey in the freezer is advanced preparation on holiday meals. Turkey meat can be ground or diced and used as a lean replacement for beef. Turkey is delicious!

Why buy these turkeys? 
These turkeys get fresh grass twice daily, live in a natural setting, yet are protected from predators. They exhibit all their expected turkey behaviors. They have a constant supply of fresh water, and are clean and happy. They eat good food without any growth promoters. The processing is done without additives (no salt or MSG), and they are flash frozen to lock in juiciness.

Title: Pasture-raised pork for sale
Body:
Maple Valley Farm in Bloomington is taking orders for pork. Their heritage and mixed-breed pigs are raised on pasture and are free to eat grass, nuts, acorns and other food available in the pasture and woods. They are supplemented with a mixture of non-GMO corn, roasted soybeans, oats and minerals to be sure they get enough protein to grow. They are moved to fresh pastures and wooded areas regularly. The pigs are never fed medicated food, antibiotics, or steroids and nothing is added during processing. The pork will be ready in the next couple of weeks, so place your order now. For more information, see http://store.howardfamilyweb.com/10-grass-fed-pork

Larry Howard is a Rose alum who is operating Maple Valley Farm on sustainable principles.

Title: King's Island Trip This Weekend!
Body:
Hello my fellow Rosebuds. A few friends and myself are going to King's Island this Saturday, and thought it'd be pretty neat if we invited the rest of the Rose stragglers that are ever-so-joyfully stuck in Terre Haute this summer. I think we could all use some action, rollercoaster action that is. So here are the deets: 

King's Island opens at 1000 and it’s a 3-hour drive, so we're thinking of leaving Terredise at 0630. That gives a wee bit of a cushion for, well, weeing. Tickets are $31 per person for a group of 15 or more, $44 online for individual tickets, and $60 at the gate. Depending on who and how many, car-pooling is definitely going to be the tactic in the transportation arena, unless someone owns some pretty fast camels that we could borrow, that’d be chill too. I’m down with camels. 

Just send me an email at costonbj@rose-hulman.edu if you're interested in going so I can start to get some idea of the car-pooling situation. Toodles

Title: Camper, deck, dock, and Jon boat for sale
Body: My parents are selling their trailer they have parked at Wilderness Lake in Martinsville, Illinois (about 40 minutes from here) The price we are asking includes the trailer,  deck, a dock, and a Jon boat with trolling motor. The trailer is a 1980 model, 21 feet long and the interior is outdated. Remember that brown and orange shag from the 80’s? Well, this place has it! It has been a great get away but because of health issues, they are selling.  They are asking $2,000 for everything and it is being sold in “As in condition”. The trailer has 1 bedroom and a couch in the living room that folds out to a bed.  Contact me for pictures if interested.

Title: Press Conference for Grand Challenges Course - Aug 5 Tuesday
Body:
Please see the note below from the summer grand challenges course.  The students will be holding a real press conference on Tuesday with members of the local media.  The grand challenges course is a 12 credit multidisciplinary offering with design, science, and technical communication elements.

For additional information, contact Ryan, Dale Long, or Professor Bernal.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

Hello Everyone,
 
This summer, the Rose-Hulman Summer Grand Challenge team has been working on a project that will improve life for people in Haiti.
 
Our team will be hosting a press conference this coming Tuesday, August 5th at 1:30 p.m. at the Branam Innovation Center and would like to invite you to come learn about our 9 foot, solar cooker and the recycled plastic building material we have developed!
 
We look forward to seeing you there.
 
Thank you,
Ryan
Ryan G. Tanaka
Bachelor of Science, Civil Engineering 2016
CELL: (949) 525-6762

Title: Moodle Workshops - Friday, August 22
Body:
Please join us for two active, hands-on workshops, open to anyone teaching a Rose-Hulman course.  Both workshops will be offered Friday, August 22, following the CPSE Teaching Workshop.
 
If you are new to Moodle, or use it to post materials but feel a little nervous about using the gradebook, please bring your laptop and join us for Moodle Fundamentals: 1:45 – 3:00 p.m., Olin 167.
Topics covered will include:
1.  Moodle Navigation
2.  Editing Course Settings
3.  Setting up the Gradebook
4.  Adding Activities & Resources
5.  Common FAQ's (merging courses, uploading/transferring content from one Moodle course to another, etc.)
 
If you’re comfortable with the topics listed above, and would like to see what else Moodle can do for you, please bring your laptop and join us for Getting More out of Moodle: 3:15 – 4:30 p.m., Olin 167.
Topics covered will include:
1. Gradebook Tools: Rubrics, Marking Guide, Checklist
2.  Quizzes, Questionnaires, and Surveys
3.  Discussion Forum options 
 
Please RSVP for either or both workshops by emailing dee@rose-hulman.edu.

Title: Revised Summer Exercise Class Schedule
Body:
Zumba will meet the rest of the summer 3 days per week beginning this week. Classes will be Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday starting at 5:15pm. Due to floor repairs in the SRC Multi-Purpose Room, Zumba will meet in the SRC Fieldhouse this week only.
 
Beginning Monday August 18th, the 12:15 Tone and Tighten class will resume. This class will continue to meet Monday through Thursday. Monday's class will be held in the SRC Multi-Purpose Room.

Title: 5K Engineers without Borders
Body: Hey Rose-Hulman runners, walkers, joggers, and staggerers, come join Engineers without Borders at our first 5K race in Hawthorn Park on October 18th!  Registration forms can be found attached, on our website at www.rose-hulman.edu/ewb<http://www.rose-hulman.edu/ewb>, or by contacting philliaa@rose-hulman.edu<mailto:philliaa@rose-hulman.edu>. $5.00 race no shirt, $15.00 race and short sleeve cotton shirt, or $25.00 race and long sleeve tech shirt. All proceeds will go towards latrines in Ghana. Hope to see you there!

Title: Cheerleading Tryouts! Tomorrow September 2!
Body:
Cheerleading Tryouts! 
For Both Cheerleaders and Lifters (Both Females & Males)
 
Tuesday, September 2 *7pm—9pm SRC Multipurpose Room
&
Wednesday, September 3 *6pm  SRC Hulbert Arena
 
Important Tryout Info:  http://athletics.rose-hulman.edu/sports/cheer/index 
 
*Attendance is mandatory on September 2 to be able to tryout on September 3. 
- You must fill out an application found on the link above or come early to fill it out at registration on September 2. 
- Attire: Shorts, PLAIN t-shirt or PLAIN, full-length sports top, cheer shoe or tennis shoe with a soft sole, all hair pulled back, girls & guys must wear cheer briefs or compression shorts or briefs, girls must wear sports bras. ALL ATTIRE MUST BE CLEAN! 
 
Good Luck! 
Coach, 
Mackenzie Valandingham
valandin@rose-hulman.edu

Title: I HAVE A LAKESIDE 1 LOFT TO SELL TO YOU, MY FRIEND!
Body:
Hello, 

I have a seven-foot tall loft that I am looking to sell.  It is meant to cover the back part of a lakeside 1 room.  

365 days ago, I hand-crafted this loft in my humble, tall, empty lakeside 1 living space.  A lot of money was put into purchasing only the high quality pieces of wood and screws from Menard's; each piece of wood was inspected carefully to ensure the longevity and stability of the loft. The upper level is supported by eight pillars of wood, and there are also some extra pieces of wood, if they buyer wants to make the structure even more stable than it already is.

The price that I am asking for this one-of-a-kind, customizable, never-before-seen, #ThisLoftIsSuperAwesome loft is $200, but am willing to negotiate.  Please email me at chonge@rose-hulman.edu if interested, and I can send you some pictures of what the loft looks like.

Thanks,

Elena

Title: FREE Amazon Prime!
Body: What a wonderful time of the year: summer is coming to an end, classes are starting, and our in-boxes are flooded with Sharepoints looking to buy and sell books. On the off chance you can't find your required books, Amazon.com usually has the best prices! And if you have a Prime account 2-day shipping is FREE! (Order today and get your books in time for classes on Thursday). Follow this link:http://www.amazon.com/gp/student/signup/info?ie=UTF8&refcust=WR333ZVLZDU5BSTXQTJ2ZWXKUM&ref_type=generic and register with your .edu email address to receive a FREE Amazon Student account with FREE Prime benefits for 6 months and close to a 50% discount for 4 years after!

Title: Learn@Lunch Session: Worm Composting - Thursday, September 18, 2014
Body:
Learn @ Lunch Session
Worm Composting
 
Thursday, September 18, 2014
11:45 a.m. - 12:35 p.m.
 
HMU - Heritage Room
Speaker: Candace Minster
 
Composting with worms is a fun, space-saving way to reduce the impact of your biodegradable food waste. Candace Minster, the Garden Manager and Fiber Arts Coordinator at the White Violet Center for Ec0-Justice will teach you how to set up and maintain a worm bin and get answers to some frequently-asked questions. You don’t need lots of space for a worm bin — they can even be kept indoors!
Candace Minster has been employed for over 10 years at the White Violet Center for Eco-Justice. Her areas of expertise include organic gardening, worm composting, food preservation (canning and fermentation), beginning beekeeping, fiber arts (knitting, spinning and weaving) and fiber processing. Candace is a passionate advocate for developing sustainable and just local food systems.
The White Violet Center for Eco-Justice exists to provide opportunities for many persons to participate in creating systems that support justice and sustainability, locally and globally. Through organic agriculture, eco-justice education and social advocacy, White Violet Center strives to promote an awareness and way of living which supports life. 
To register, please click here. Spouses are welcome to attend!

Title: [All Students] FREE AMAZON STUDENT MEMBERSHIP
Body: What a wonderful time of the year: summer is coming to an end, classes are starting, and our in-boxes are flooded with Sharepoints looking to buy and sell books. On the off chance you can't find your required books, Amazon.com usually has the best prices! And if you have a Prime account 2-day shipping is FREE! (Order today and get your books in time for classes on Thursday). Follow this link :http://www.amazon.com/gp/student/signup/info?ie=UTF8&refcust=WR333ZVLZDU5BSTXQTJ2ZWXKUM&ref_type=generic and register with your .edu email address to receive a FREE Amazon Student account with FREE Prime benefits for 6 months and close to a 50% discount for 4 years after!

Title: Math Seminar- Wednesday, September 10, 2014 9th Period
Body:
RHIT Mathematics Colloquium
Wednesday, September 10, 2014 9th period – 3:25 p.m. to 4:15 p.m., G220
 
Presenter: Dr. Will Green Rose-Hulman Institute of TechnologyDepartment of Mathematics

 
TITLE: “ Three men, a monkey and some coconuts”
 
 
Abstract:   We will discuss (and solve) a classic mathematical riddle posed by Martin Gardner in 1961.  In addition we will explore some generalizations of this riddle and some of the different mathematical ideas and disciplines arise naturally from trying to solve these related problems.  No mathematical knowledge will be assumed, all are welcome to join in.
 
 
 
 
REFRESHMENTS SERVED

Title: Research Participation Opportunity
Body:
Dear Rose-Hulman Students: 
 
You are invited to participate in a research study about learning; specifically, this study is an investigation of the effects of body posture on learning. By participating in this study, you may discover body postures that increase your learning. 
 
We request the participation of students who are 18 or older. You may be required to hold poses such as crossed-arms and legs propped upon a table for ten minutes. This study is being conducted by Alayna B. McNamara and Ella Ingram, from the Department of Biology and Biomedical Engineering at Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology; therefore, if you are currently enrolled in any of Dr. Ingram’s or Ms. McNamara’s courses, you are unable to participate. 
 
If you choose to participate, you may first complete a trial that measures your confidence. This trial may last up to 30 minutes, scheduled at your convenience. If you complete this trial, you will receive $5 in Declining Balance. Additionally, you may be asked to participate in several trials on learning. Each of these sessions should last approximately 60 minutes, scheduled at your convenience. Participation in this study may involve up to five different trials; after the completion of each trial, you will receive $10 in cash; if you complete the entirety of the trials, you will receive a $20 completion bonus in cash. 
 
You may withdraw from the study at any time, and if you choose to do so, you will be compensated for your time and any data collected from you will be destroyed and not utilized in any subsequent analysis. 
 
Thank you for your consideration to participate in this research study. Please contact either of us if you would like to enroll or have other questions. 
 
Alayna B. McNamara mcnamaab@rose-hulman.ed 
 
Dr. Ella Ingram ingram@rose-hulman.edu 
 
IRB Number: 442867 IRB Approval Date: 4/15/14

Title: IM Tennis Registration opens TODAY!!
Body:
* Registration for Intramural Tennis begins today, Monday, September 8th. The registration deadline for IM Tennis is Thursday, September 18th. Please log onto www.imleagues.com to register yourself, or doubles team, by the September 18th deadline. If you have any questions or concerns, please contact Jordan Barrett at barrett1@rose-hulman.edu or ext. 8961.





Intramural Tennis Registration

Who: Open to all Rose-Hulman students (not Rose-Hulman tennis players), faculty, and staff. There will be Residence Hall, Greek and Independent leagues for both singles and doubles.  

What: IM Tennis leagues. There are not set days and times for IM tennis. You will contact your opponent and set up a day and time to play that is convenient for your schedule. Winners will then contact the IM Graduate Assistant, Mike Frassetto at frassett@rose-hulman.edu.

When: Registration begins today, Monday September 8th. The Registration Deadline will be Thursday, September 18th. To register as an individual or a doubles team, please log onto www.imleagues.com. Scroll over the player signup link and click the Create Team button at the top right of your User Homepage. IM Tennis will begin on Monday, September 22nd.

Where: Intramural tennis matches will take place on either the Joy Hulbert Outdoor Tennis Courts (located just east of Cook Stadium) or at the indoor tennis court (located in the SRC Fieldhouse). 

Why: Intramural points will be awarded to the winning Residence Hall, Greek, and Independent individuals and teams towards the Intramural All Sport Championship. Awards will also be given to the winners (mugs or t-shirts).

Costs: NO COSTS!!! There is no forfeit fee required when you register on IMLeauges.

Additional Information: If you have any questions or concerns, please feel free to contact Jordan Barrett at ext. 8961 or barrett1@rose-hulman.edu. 
 

Thank you!
 
Jordan Barrett
Assistant Director for Recreational Sports and Athletic Facilities, Intramurals/Club Sports and Special Events
Phone: (812)877-8961
Cell: (812)201-7903
Fax: (812)877-8969

5500 Wabash Avenue, CM37
Terre Haute, IN  47803

Title: Using git for version control
Body:
Using git for version control
Wednesday, September 10
10th hour, F225
by Micah Taylor


Git is a distributed version control system that is fast and flexible. I'll talk about how to interface with SVN servers, basic everyday use, and introduce git's powerful branching capabilities. Bring your computer if you want to try it out!

Title: Sabbatical Experience - Dr. Maarij Syed
Body:
Dr. Maarij Syed
Professor
Department of Physics and Optical Engineering
 
 
*The Department of Physics and Optical Engineering is pleased to announce that Dr. Maarij Syed will give a presentation on his sabbatical experience in Myers 137 beginning at 3:25 p.m. on Friday, September 12, 2014.  
 
Friday, September 12, 2014
Beginning at 3:25 p.m.
Myers 137
 
 
AbstractSabbatical Leave: Why it’s good for you (and why it is not)!
 
I spent my sabbatical year working on a variety of projects. Some of these projects represented a continuation of work that I have been engaged in for the last few years. Others represented forays into new areas. Before the start of my sabbatical I had three students who were working on various aspects of this project. Two of the three were senior who were planning to do their undergraduate thesis on work in this area. Given the quality of their work and my commitment to them, I made myself available to them throughout this year. Evidence of this was the fact that I supervised eight research hours of coursework during my sabbatical year. This was also made possible by the fact that my other projects resulted in some travel but otherwise did not require me to move to a different university or research center.
In this presentation I would like to share with you what I have learned and how I see this valuable experience as providing me with opportunities and ideas for future research and professional growth.
 
            
 
Refreshments served.

Title: Registration for Indoor Soccer and Flag Football Ends TODAY!!
Body:
* The registration deadline for IM Flag Football and Indoor Soccer is today, Wednesday, September 10th. 

Please be sure to register your team on www.imleagues.com by the September 10th registration deadline date. IM Flag Football will be played on Monday and Tuesday and Indoor Soccer will be on Wednesday and Thursday. If you have any questions or concerns about registering, please contact Jordan Barrett at barrett1@rose-hulman.edu or at ext. 8961.




 


IM Flag Football & Indoor Soccer Registration


Who: Open to all Rose-Hulman students (not Rose-Hulman football or soccer players), faculty, and staff. There will be Residence Hall, Greek and Independent leagues for both IM sports. 



What: Intramural Flag Football & Indoor Soccer leagues. Flag Football will be on Mondays and Tuesdays and Indoor Soccer will be on Wednesdays and Thursdays. 



When: The registration deadline for both IM Flag Football & IM Indoor Soccer is Wednesday, September 10th. To register a team, please log onto www.imleagues.com. Click the Create Team button at the top right of your User Homepage. Games will begin on Monday, September 15th for Flag Football and Wednesday, September 17th for Indoor Soccer.



Where: IM Flag Football will be played at the IM Fields, which are just east of the outdoor tennis courts. IM Indoor Soccer will be played in the SRC Fieldhouse, which is located in the lower level of the SRC.



How to Register: Log in to your IMLeagues account. Click the Create Team button at the top right of your User Homepage or click the Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology link to go to our homepage on IMLeagues. The current sports will be displayed, click on the sport you wish to join. Choose the league you wish to play in (Greek A, Res Hall B, Independent C, etc...).



Why: Intramural points will be awarded to the winning Residence Hall, Greek, and Independent teams toward the Intramural All Sport Championship (the Residence Hall, Independent team, and Fraternity who have the most points at the end of the year will be awarded the overall Intramural Sports Champions and will be given the travelling trophy). Awards will also be given to the winning teams (either mugs or t-shirts).



Costs: A $20 forfeit fee is required. Please be sure to submit your $20 forfeit fee to the IM Office (either by taking it to the IM Office 265 D or sending it through campus mail to Dan O'Leary at CM 37) by Friday the 12th of September. Your team will NOT be able to play until you submit your $20 forfeit fee per team.



Free Agents: An Intramural Free Agent is a Rose-Hulman student, faculty, or staff member who wishes to participate in an Intramural sponsored team activity and is not currently a member of a team. The Free Agent list will be posted in the Intramural Office. If you would like to be put on the Free Agent List, please do so by e-mailing Jordan Barrett at barrett1@rose-hulman.edu. When e-mailing, please include name, sport you would like to join, contact number, and e-mail address.
 
The Intramural Department for the 2014-15 academic year is sponsored by ArcelorMittal



 



Hope you all have a great year here at Rose!
 

Jordan Barrett
Assistant Director for Recreational Sports and Athletic Facilities, Intramurals/Club Sports and Special Events
Phone: (812)877-8961
Cell: (812)201-7903
Fax: (812)877-8969

5500 Wabash Avenue, CM37
Terre Haute, IN  47803

Title: Interest for cryptocurrency club?
Body:
Hey, everyone. Given the quick and easy nature of club-founding at Rose-Hulman, I thought it may be worth it to see if I could get together a group of people interested in cryptocurrencies (Bitcoin, Litecoin, Dogecoin, etc.) and possibly create a club if there's enough interest. Potential activities include:

* Weekly meetings to discuss new happenings in the world of cryptocoins - For example, the release of GAW Miners' new "Hashlet" model of ASIC miners.

* Occasional seminars open to all students, giving information about cryptocurrencies and handing out free "paper wallet" gifts that contain a small amount of one cryptocurrency.

* Coordinating a "group-buy" for a Rose-Hulman ASIC unit.

* Discussing possible applications for the use of cryptocurrency on-campus - For example, enabling on-campus stores (such as the bookstore) to accept Bitcoin or other cryptocurrencies.

If anyone is already involved in cryptocurrencies or would like to become involved, please email me at kuhnerdm@rose-hulman.edu. I will probably end up making a Skype/Lync group for us so that we can discuss getting the club started. Thanks!

--Derek Kuhnert

Title: Reminder - Sabbatical talk today by Dr. Syed
Body:
Dr. Maarij Syed
Associate Professor
Department of Physics and Optical Engineering
 
 
*The Department of Physics and Optical Engineering is pleased to announce that Dr. Maarij Syed will give a presentation on his sabbatical experience in Myers 137 beginning at 3:25 p.m. on Friday, September 12, 2014.  
 
Friday, September 12, 2014
Beginning at 3:25 p.m.
Myers 137
 
 
AbstractSabbatical Leave: Why it’s good for you (and why it is not)!
 
I spent my sabbatical year working on a variety of projects. Some of these projects represented a continuation of work that I have been engaged in for the last few years. Others represented forays into new areas. Before the start of my sabbatical I had three students who were working on various aspects of this project. Two of the three were senior who were planning to do their undergraduate thesis on work in this area. Given the quality of their work and my commitment to them, I made myself available to them throughout this year. Evidence of this was the fact that I supervised eight research hours of coursework during my sabbatical year. This was also made possible by the fact that my other projects resulted in some travel but otherwise did not require me to move to a different university or research center.
In this presentation I would like to share with you what I have learned and how I see this valuable experience as providing me with opportunities and ideas for future research and professional growth.
 
            
 
Refreshments served.

Title: Free Money, Amazon Prime Signups, and the angry ramblings of a tired man...
Body:
So a few people have deemed it necessary to spam our already-cluttered Sharepoints with a free student Amazon prime signup link.

I'm already not a fan of how Sharepoint is used (for books, that whole HJR-6 debacle, etc.) but I'm not up on my soapbox to rant about that.

To the point - as of September 1st, Amazon released a new promotion, that allows people to earn $3 whenever somebody else signs up for a free prime account with their referral link.

Now, I think that promotion is a pretty cool idea - but Sharepoint is not the place for you to rake in cash.

EVEN SO, if you somehow deem it necessary to spam Sharepoint to make your money (as 4 people apparently already have), at least inform your audience about what you're doing.

But for God's sake, shut up, or so help me...

Title: Chemistry and Biochemistry Speaker Seminar
Body:
Fundamental and Delightful Connections Between Mechanical Engineering and Chemistry

                                      Allen R. White, Ph.D.

                                  Wednesday, September 17,
                                                4th Hour
                                                  G315

Chemistry is at the core of many mechanical engineering areas, such as internal combustion engines.  More significantly, measurement techniques that are central to chemistry also offer significant potential insight into engineering systems.  For example, Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy and Time-of Flight Mass Spectrometry (TOFMS) give insight into combustion initiation and propagation mechanisms.  Conveniently, some engineering systems offer potential new applications in analytical chemistry.  Dr. White spent the 2013-14 academic year in the Hieftje Laboratory for Spectrochemistry in the Department of Chemistry at Indiana University Bloomington and will discuss these connections, specifically chemical analysis of internal combustion engines, and the application of an automotive spark system as an ambient ionization source for mass spectrometry.

Title: IM Badminton Registration opens Today!!!
Body:
* Registration for the IM Badminton Tournament begins today, Monday, September 15th. The registration deadline is Thursday, September 25th. To register, please log onto www.imleagues.com and register before the September 25th deadline. The IM Badminton Tournament will begin on Monday, September 29th. If you have any questions or concerns, please feel free to contact Jordan Barrett at barrett1@rose-hulman.edu or ext. 8961.







IM Badminton Registration


Who: Open to all Rose-Hulman students, faculty, and staff. There will be Residence Hall, Greek and Independent leagues for both singles and doubles.


What: IM Badminton Leagues. There will not be set days and times for IM Badminton (much like IM Tennis and IM Racquetball). You will contact your opponent and set up a day and time to play that is convenient for your schedule. Winners will then contact IM GA, Mike Frassetto @ frassett@rose-hulman.edu.


When: Registration begins today, Monday, September 15th. The Registration Deadline will be Thursday, September 25th. To register as an individual or a doubles team, please log onto www.imleagues.com. Scroll over the player signup link and click the Create Team button at the top right of your User Homepage. IM Badminton will begin on Monday, September 29th.


Where: IM Badminton matches will take place in the SRC Fieldhouse. For directions to the Badminton Courts, please contact Jordan Barrett.


Why: Intramural points will be awarded to the winning Residence Hall, Greek, and Independent individuals and teams towards the Intramural All Sports Championship. Awards will also be given to the winners (mugs or t-shirts). 


Costs: NO COSTS!!! There is no forfeit fee required when you register on IMLeagues. 


Additional Information:  If you have any questions or concerns, please feel free to contact Jordan Barrett at ext. 8961 or barrett1@rose-hulman.edu.

Title: 24 Hour Student Access Petition - Delivered to President Conwell Today
Body:
Hello everybody,

I wanted to update the campus on the status of the 24 Hour Student Access Petition that I have created. 

Over the last four days, I have obtained roughly 1280 signatures from students who believe that we should have access to the academic buildings and the BIC 24 hours each day. I have attached the letter that was delivered to President Conwell earlier today.

Thank you for all of your support, and hopefully this helps to ensure that our voices are heard.

Mike Jones

Title: Guest Speaker “There is No Map For Where You’re Going”, Wed. 9/17, 4:20pm, E104
Body:
Join us for a Guest Speaker
Hosted by the ESCALATE Program and the RISE Club
 
“There is No Map For Where You’re Going”
 
Speaker:
Grant Hoffman
Professor of Practice, Rose-Hulman
 
Formerly of:
Cook Medical, Cleveland Clinic
 
 Wednesday, September 17
10th Hour – 4:20 PM
Room : E-104
 
 
Grant Hoffman is a Rose-Hulman alum and is back on campus serving as Professor of Practice in the KEEN entrepreneurship program.  Prior to coming back to Rose, Grant worked at Cook Medical and the Cleveland Clinic in a variety of product development and technology commercialization roles.
 
Grant will talk about how his career path has never been planned and why it won’t be in the future.  He will talk about what he thought he wanted to do, why he took certain opportunities, and why it all ended up the way it did. 
 
Refreshments will be served.

Title: Metal Band Seeking Members!
Body:
​Hello all you musically inclined
engineers! We are currently seeking musicians who enjoy playing metal/metalcore
to fill a few open spots in our current lineup.
We are working on a variety of
music drawing influence from August Burns Red, Volumes, SikTh, Becoming the
Archetype, Glass Cloud, As I Lay Dying, Fit For A King, and Born of Osiris.
Most of our music is being
written in drop tuning or on extended range instruments (7 or 8 string guitar
and 5 string bass). We usually practice on Friday nights in a garage off
campus. We have some equipment for you to use including a 4 piece drum set and
extra amps so all we need is you! If interested please contact Jim at tumavijr@rose-hulman.edu or
630-287-0903 for more information.​

Title: Entrepreneurship/Robotics Speaker - Oct 23 - 10th - E104
Body:
Join the Escalate student group on Thursday, Oct 23, 10th period in E-104 to hear about Adev Automation.  Tyler Masterson, recent Rose grad, is a founder of Adev.   
Adev Automation is a startup robotics company in the early stages ofbusiness and technology development. Our robot is designed for the agricultural worldto harvest strawberries. We proved the concept first by trackingstrawberries with a cheap webcam, and then moved our way up to asystem of stereo webcams and a time-of-flight 3D camera. We willdiscuss our sensors and the image processing that takes place in orderto find, track, and pick the strawberries.​

Body:
Another session will be scheduled in spring 2015.
 
Intramurals
Wednesday, October 22, 2014
9:50 – 10:40 a.m.
HMU - Heritage Room
Presenter: Jordan Barrett, Assistant Director for Intramurals, Club Sports and Special Events
Did you know that faculty and staff can participate in intramurals at Rose-Hulman? Jordan will discuss the sports that Rose-Hulman offers and how you can get involved.
To register, please click here.

Title: Learn@Lunch: Holiday Sugar Cookie Decorating - Thursday, November 13, 2014
Body:
Holiday Sugar Cookie Decorating
 
Thursday, November 13th
11:45 a.m. – 12:35 p.m.
HMU – Heritage Room
 
In preparation for the upcoming holiday season, November’s Learn@Lunch presentation will focus on teaching attendees the art of holiday sugar cookie decorating. The owners of Bites and Blessings, Heather Mucci and Darby Schimmel, will teach attendees how to create beautiful sugar cookie designs using frosting and edible food décor items. Heather and Darby will provide cookie recipes and hands on instructions on how to properly decorate sugar cookies. Attendees will decorate cookies along with the presenters. 
 
 
The creators behind Bites and Blessings are Heather Mucci and Darby Schimmel.   Heather and Darby’s goal is to turn any event or party into a gourmet celebration.  They specialize in custom decorated sugar cookies.  However, they also provide many other sweet treats such as:  cake pops, cupcakes, signature popcorn, signature trail mixes, munch and crunch treats, old fashioned soda pops and specialty dipped cookies on sticks. You can check out their website at www.bitesandblessings.com  or follow them on Facebook by searching Bites and Blessings.
 
 
To register, please click here. 
Please register as soon as possible so that the presenters can provide enough materials for everyone.

Title: Free Event at ISU: American humanitarian aid worker to speak about genocide in Rwanda
Body:
Humanitarian aid worker Carl Wilkens will share his story as the only American to remain in Rwanda after genocide began in 1994 when he presents at Indiana State University on Oct. 24 at 5 p.m.

​

The presentation, entitled "Rwandan Genocide: Against the Tutsi: The Power of Presence/Choice, the Power of Stories and Service to Combat Genocide, Prejudice, Bigotry and Bullying," will recount when genocide broke out in country in April 1994, four years after Wilkens and his family moved to Rwanda.
It is Free event to the public.​


Click here for Tribstar News.


More info.

Title: Special Seminar Monday 10th: Ebola Unmasked, Dr. Mary Anne Luzar, National Institutes of Health
Body:
​Ebola Unmasked: International Efforts to Halt the Current
Epidemic and the Bioethical Challenges Facing Each Approach
Monday, November 10th,
4:20/10th, GM Room​
Mary Anne Luzar, Ph.D. Chief of
the Regulatory Affairs Branch, Division of AIDS, National Institute of Allergy
and Infectious Diseases with the National Institutes of Health.
This lecture will focus on the current
developments regarding the Ebola pandemic and its global impact in areas of
public health, ethics, and economics. It will trace the history of earlier
Ebola outbreaks and discuss the current preparation in the U.S. for what may
come in the future. A review of the research to find a treatment will be
discussed. Other pandemics have taught us valuable lessons and we will explore
how they may inform the current public health decision makers.
Mary
Anne Luzar, Ph.D. is a microbiologist by training and is Chief of the
Regulatory Affairs Branch, Division of AIDS, National Institute of Allergy and
Infectious Diseases, National Institutes of Health. She joined the Division of
AIDS in 1992 and is the Division’s official liaison to the FDA for clinical
research protocols related to HIV treatment and prevention. Dr. Luzar manages a
group of regulatory professionals who oversee Investigational New Drug
applications for several hundred Phase I-IV human clinical trials conducted in
the United States and around the world. Prior to joining the NIH, Dr. Luzar was
Senior Principle Scientist in the Renal Division of Baxter Corporation in the
European Baxter R&D Center in Nivelles, Belgium. While there, her
microbiology research efforts focused on renal product development and
international human clinical trials related to reducing infections during
peritoneal dialysis. Prior to pursuing her career in science, Dr. Luzar worked
in the International Trade Center in the European Headquarters of the United
Nations in Geneva, Switzerland.

Title: ROSE-BUD Technical Talk: Raquel Hill, Indiana University, School of Informatics and Computing
Body:
​Thursday, November 13, 2014
9th hour in GM Room
Reception will follow and refreshments will be served in CSSE Lab, F226
Rose-BUD
is sponsoring a technical talk from Raquel Hill, an Associate Professor of
Computer Science in the School of Informatics and Computing. Her primary
research interests are in the areas of trust and security of distributed
computing environments and data privacy with a specific interest in privacy
protection mechanisms for medical-related datasets. She holds B.S. and M.S.
degrees in Computer Science from the Georgia Institute of Technology and a
Ph.D. in Computer Science from Harvard University.
Dr.
Hill will be talking about her research involving data privacy related to the
work of behavioral scientists. In this work, Dr. Hill seeks to determine
whether attributes that make a participant unique within a high-dimensional
social science dataset can be used to identify that individual. She will also
present new results of a use-case analysis that evaluates Differential Privacy
as a technique to protect behavioral science datasets while preserving their
research utility. The essential goal is to prevent a possible adversary from
discovering whether or not some specific individual's data is present in a
differentially private dataset, given some risk threshold.​
ECE Professional Development Credit Available
Everyone Invited

Title: Seminar - Intellectual Property Protection - Weds Nov 12 at 4:30
Body:
​


Join us for a seminar on IP protection:
 
Intellectual Property
Protection in New Ventures and New Product Development
By Jim Coles of Densborn Blachly LLP   http://densbornblachly.com/attorneys/jim-coles/
 
Wednesday, November 12 at 4:30 in the Kahn Room
Food and drink provided after the presentation.
 
Jim will present an in depth look at approaches for
protecting IP including discussion of a case study.
We often think of IP protection as simply ‘getting a patent’
and Jim take a broader view of the issues involved.

Title: Cryptocurrency Club Meeting 11/14 at 7 PM
Body:
​Hello, everyone! It's been a while since I've sent out a message about Cryptocurrency Club, but I feel like this meeting coming up is going to be pretty cool! We're going to be talking about mining on proof of work systems, one of the most important aspects of concepts like Bitcoin. Also, the information given at the meeting can be applied to potentially earn some extra change by mining cryptocurrencies! We'll be on the second floor of the union at 7 PM TOMORROW (11/14), out by where the couches are. Hope you all can make it!

--Derek Kuhnert

Title: On Campus Job! $9.50/hour No Work Study Required!
Body:
​


The Rose Hulman Phonathon is hiring for the Holidays!
Starting on the first day of Winter quarter the Phonathon will be hiring
students for our open caller positions. We are looking for hardworking outgoing
students who love Rose and want to make a difference for their fellow students!
Reasons to work here
1.)   
Flex scheduling! Only 7 hours per week and you
set your schedule each week!
2.)   
Great Pay! Starting at $9.50 per hour with a
potential for raises and bonuses!
3.)   
Great on a Resume! Build communication skills
vital to any successful resume and network with Alumni!
4.)   
Great Working Environment! Games and prizes on
every shift, free food, and fun people!
If interested email Wes Kayser at Wesley.kayser@ruffalocody.com

Title: Job opening - Grader for the Math Dept
Body:
The Math Dept. has one to two openings to grade MA381 for the Winter Quarter.  If you have either Work Study or Work Opportunity funding for the 2014-15 Academic Year and received a B or higher in the course, please stop by G205 to discuss the position with the Secretary.  We prefer to hire students who don't already have a job on campus; if you feel you can handle the workload of two jobs, we can discuss this in person. 
I need to fill the job opening by Friday, November 28th.  If we are unable to fill the position with someone who has Work Study, we will consider paying the student from the Math Dept. budget.  ​

Title: SimplyWell Session: External Influences on Food Choices & Weight Management - Tuesday, December 9, 2014
Body:
External Influences on Food Choices & Weight Management
Tuesday, December 9, 2014
1:35 – 2:25 p.m.
HMU - PA Room
 
Presenter: Traci Arini, RD, CD, CDE, Union Hospital Diabetes Education Center
Traci returns to present on external influences and how they can impact our food choices and weight management. 
This SimplyWell session is part of the Maintain, Don’t Gain Wellness Challenge.
SimplyWell participants not participating in the challenge are welcome to attend this event and earn 250 Wellness Events points.
Spouses are welcome to attend.
 
To register, please click here.  If you need assistance logging into iModules for the first time, please contact Pamela Pahnke at ext. 8916.
Please be sure to record your points within 90 days of the event.

Title: subleasing from the spring through summer and summer through fall
Body:
​I am looking for someone to sublease my apartment from the
spring quarter through the summer; my roommate is looking to do the same from
the summer through the fall. But if just interested for one quarter we are willing to think about it. We live at Heritage Trail Apartments and are
hoping for someone to move in while we aren’t at school. We are willing to talk
and negotiate on pricing and our place is completely furnished including a
comfortable living room with a TV, all kitchen utensils, bed, dresser, etc. The
apartment is a 2 bedroom 2 bath, you would have your own bath and room. If
interested please contact either myself (chloe.lavelle@rose-hulman.edu,

Title: Christmas in the Park
Body:
​The 28th
annual Christmas in the Park is being held at Deming Park (500 So. Fruitridge
Ave.) beginning Monday December 1, 2014. 
Nineteen park shelters have been decorated by non-profit organizations
in town.  The lights will be on from 5:00
– 10:00 p.m. each night from December 1st through December 28th.


Holiday Train rides will
be available from 6:00 – 8:00 p.m. with different organizations hosting them on.  There is a fee for the train rides and
carriage rides.  


Santa Claus has his own
house at the park (located on the west side). 
He will be there December 1 (6 to 9:00 p.m.); December 6 and 7 (5:00 –
8:00 p.m.), December 8 (6:00 – 9:00 p.m.) and December 13 and 14 (5:00 – 8:00
p.m.)  There is no charge to visit him
and parents are encouraged to bring their own cameras.


Approximately 75,000 people
view these lights each year.


There is no cost to enter
the park.

Title: Selling: UPS Uninterruptable Power Supply
Body:
​For sale: Cyber Power Systems 425VA
uninterruptable power supply. A UPS doesn't really help you with a
laptop computer since they have a battery built in, but it can be
very useful with a desktop computer or other equipment when you want
to have time to save your work and shut down properly in case of
unexpectedly losing power. The one I am selling is like the model
described at this link, except it does NOT have the USB port for
automated shutdown:
http://www.cyberpowersystems.com/products/ups-systems/soho-ups/cp425slg.html


Features: 

425 Volt-amp capacity;
4 outlets with battery backup, two of
them spaced wide for use with transformer bricks;
4 outlets with surge protection only,
two of them spaced wide;
Surge protection for phone line (not
ethernet) with one line-in port and two line-out ports.


You can find this new online for about
forty dollars; this one is about one and a half years old and is
priced at $20. 



Contact me at
john.m.gardner@rose-hulman.edu​

Title: Invitation to Artist Soulaf Abas' book signing benefiting Syrian refugee children
Body:
​Colleagues:
Please forgive the use of mass email to bring to your attention a wonderful
upcoming event by Syrian Artist and Adjunct Art Professor at Indiana State,
Soulaf Abas. For more details please read the Tribune Star’s in depth article
on her journey and commitment to the children of Syria, ‘Seen
for Syria': Artist pours heart into helping people of her native land. I
hope to see some of you at the Swope next Thursday. Feel free to share this far
and wide.
Thank
you and Happy Holidays! 
Mackenzie
________________________
We
would like to invite you to the book signing of "Me and You: a letter and art exchange between Syrian refugee
children and American
children" by: Soulaf Abas
This
book documents letters and art exchange between children from Ryves Hall, Terre Haute, Indiana and
Syrian refugee children in Amman, Jordan. The book is part of the art
initiative "Seen for Syria" by Syrian artist, Soulaf Abas, which is an art therapy
and education program for Syrian children in Jordan.
When:
Thursday, Dec 11th 6:00- 9:00 pm
Where:
Swope Art Museum
100% of the proceeds of the book will go to the Syrian children who participated in
this correspondence
Preorders
are available via: www.soulafabas.com/p/books.html
If
you are interested in any of the artwork on the website, 50% of the proceeds go
to Syrian children as well.
This
activity is made possible by Art Illiana and Indiana Arts Commission
contact
info: Soulaf Abas (soulafabas@gmail.com) ​

Title: CSSE Seminar
Body:
​

Computer Science and Software Engineering
Seminar


 


Designing Effective Task Training Strategies for
Human-Robot Instruction


 


Allison Sauppe


 


University of Wisconsin-Madison


 


Tuesday, December 16, 2014, 4:20 PM, Olin 167


 


Robots are becoming increasingly visible members of society, from
working in factories to helping in the home. As robots move from working alone
to collaborating alongside humans, there are many technical and design
challenges that have yet to be overcome. This talk will focus on the potential
of robots to instruct human users in a task, investigating how a robot can
provide its students with instructions in a way that maximizes their task
performance. I will present the design process for creating an autonomous
instructional robot that instructs users in a pipe assembly task. Additionally,
I will discuss key instructional strategies human instructors use, their
implementation on a robot, and their evaluation in a human-robot task. The
results from the evaluation reveal tradeoffs between instructional strategies,
offering implications for the design of instructional robots and directions for
future work.


 


Everyone is welcome to attend!

Title: CSSE Seminar
Body:
​

Computer Science and Software Engineering
Seminar


 


BOSS: An Optimization Framework for Causal Inference with
Observational Data


 


Jason J. Sauppe


 


University of Illinois


 


Monday, December 15, 2014, 4:20 PM, Olin 167


 


Causal inference is the process of identifying
relationships between events and outcomes, and it is used in a wide range of
scientific fields. A well-known example is the clinical trial, where treatment
and control groups are formed and studied to determine the efficacy of a new
drug or vaccine. In many situations the available data is observational, or
non-random, which presents particular challenges for causal inference. The
Balance Optimization Subset Selection (BOSS) model is designed to address these
difficulties by identifying an appropriate subset of data from which causal
estimates can be constructed. BOSS accomplishes this by formulating and solving
a discrete optimization problem. This talk will explore the computational
complexity of the optimization problem, both in general and for several special
cases. Approximation results will also be discussed.


 


Everyone is welcome to attend!

Title: Life Hack
Body:
Need to cook faster?
It's really simple math. If it needs 400 degrees for 20 minutes, you can instead run it at 4000 degrees for 2 minutes.​
But woah Jeffrey, I don't even HAVE an oven!
No probelm! Instead of the previous 400 degrees for 20 minutes, you can just leave it in a 40 degree refridgerator for 200 minutes! 
Proof: 400 * 20 = 8000
4000 * 2 = 8000
40 * 200 = 8000

Title: 3D Printing Project
Body:
I'm looking for someone experienced in 3D modeling and converting those models into a .stl file so the ME Dept's 3D printer can recognize it. 
The project is this: to create a case for the omni-directional IR "hats" used by CSSE120. These hats are quite fragile, so I want to ​create a protective case for them. It wouldn't be anything fancy; just a snap-on case to protect the LEDs from bending and to minimize overall wear and tear on the circutry. 
If interested, please contact me at cartersm@rose-hulman.edu or Dr. Mark Hays at hays@rose-hulman.edu.

Title: CSSE Seminar - Regaining Control of Your Online Privacy
Body:
​
Computer Science and Software Engineering Seminar Regaining Control of Your Online Privacy Sid StammPrincipal Engineer, Security and Privacy,
Mozilla Corporation, andVisiting Assistant Professor of CSSE, Rose-Hulman Wednesday, January 7, 2015, 4:20 PM, Olin 159 It seems like every day there’s a new story on the
news about how yet another company lost personal data of their employees or
customers to hackers.  But it’s not just hackers who want to trade
intricate details of your life.  On the Internet, your data is like gold
to criminals and companies alike.  To make it even more stressful, the
complexity of the online world requires someone to be a privacy expert to make
well-informed decisions about every Facebook or Snapchat sharing
decision.  So how can we make this better? This talk explores Mozilla’s
approach to helping people regain control over their online lives.  The
most effective online safety tools are not purely technological, and it is
becoming evident that we need holistic approaches that consider both the social
and technological implications of the vast Internet ecosystem.

Title: Valeo Innovation Challenge - Form a Team - Info Session Tues 9th
Body:
Please see the information below
about the upcoming Valeo Innovation Challenge.Contact Scott Johnston at johnstds@rose-hulman.edu with any
questions.  --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Hi all,Do you love automotive
technology ? Do you want to compete
against top schools from around the world in an innovation competition? Do you want to possibly
win 100,000 Euros?Come to a Valeo Innovation Challenge information meeting 9th
period on Tuesday the 20th in A220. The Valeo innovation Challenge invites student teams from
around the world to come up with a system to improve the car of 2030. Last year 1000 teams signed up including two from
Rose-Hulman. One of those teams finished within the top 20. This year, teams from the top schools in the world have
joined, including teams from MIT and Carnegie Mellon. Head to https://valeoinnovationchallenge.valeo.com/
for more information.

Title: Survey For Human Computer Interaction Project (Students & Faculty/Staff)
Body: ​Hi,Our group is collecting user data for a proposed application to keep track of club activity and events on Rose-Hulman's campus and would appriciate your input on this proposed application. This application isn't to be actually created but we will be making a prototype of the application for our Human Computer Interaction Class and we need data from possible users in order to create the best design possible. Please take a few short minutes to complete the following survey which is for any Student, member for the Faculty, or Staff.https://www.surveymonkey.com/s/GZXXXHXThanks

Title: Science Olympiad Invitational
Body: ​Hey, I was thinking about starting a Science Olympiad Invitational here at Rose next year. For those who don't know, Science Olympiad is a competitive science and engineering event for high school and middle school students. An invitational tournament would be held on a Saturday next year, probably in February or March. If anyone would be interested in helping organize or run such an event, please shoot me an email at kulbagbj@rose-hulman.eduFollow this link to the national Science Olympiad home page for more details on what it is all about. http://soinc.org/aboutThanks for your time, and again, please email me if you are interested in learning more.

Title: RISE Club Speaker - Commericalizing Academic Research - Feb 4 at 6PM
Body:
Join the RISE Club on Weds Feb 4
to hear about the venture DesignAdvance and commercializing academic research.February 4, 2014 at 6 PMOlin 169Jimmy Johns provided!Topic: DesignAdvance was founded in 2004 to commercialize an
academic research portfolio created at Carnegie Mellon University. The main
focus of the technology was to assist automotive engineers in solving various
configuration challenges. Dr. Jay McCormack, one of the co-founders of
DesignAdvance and now Associate Professor of Mechanical Engineering, will
discuss the process of transitioning academic research to a commercial product
and learning about new product opportunities.

Title: Found Dog
Body: ​Last night we found a dog roaming around in our backyard. He has no tags, no collar and is just skin and bones so it looks like he's be on his own for a while. He seems to be a mut of some kind, about a year and half old. My roommates and I are pretty sure that he doesnt have a home but we want to make sure first. So if anyone knows of someone who's lost their dog over the last few months, contact lamberjl@rose-hulman.edu to get a better description of the dog/ pictures to confirm if he is yours or not.
